transcription.title: today is a beautiful day

panel.line: Today is a beautiful day to be stomping on things! As a dinosaur, stomping on things is the best part of my day, indeed!
*gasp*
What's that, little house? You wish you were back in your own time? THAT IS TOO BAD FOR YOU
Perhaps you too will get a stomping, little girl!
WAIT!
Is stomping really the answer to your problem(s)?
Problem(s)?
My only problem(s) have to do with you interrupting my stomping!
(in small text) crazy utahraptor!

transcription.title: utaught me how to be a stupid jerk!

panel.line: I have felt the harsh sting of my own racial joke turned against me! Luckily, I've been saving a joke for just such an occasion.
All of those hours of thinking up insults for hypothetical enemies has finally paid off!
So, my racist joke somehow backfired on me.
I hope that's the last time you ever say that sentence.
Well, I've made up my own joke to get him today. All I need to do is "find that Utahraptor!"
I hope the Utahraptor is around here somewhere! My legs are giving tired.
I'm behind you.
There you are! Knock, knock.
Who's there?
Utah.
*sigh* Utah who?
Utaught me how to be a stupid jerk!
And I was a very good student!
Do you even listen to yourself?
No, but-- see, I learned it from you!

transcription.title: a journey to the moon

panel.line: A JOURNEY TO THE MOON
A RARE PROPOSITION
I propose a journey to the moon!
SEVEN YEARS LATER...
I have constructed a rocket-ship for myself and a guest of my choosing! The wood from this house will provide the fuel!
May I be your guest?
I will give your offer my consideration?
ON THE MOON...
Lunar women are good for stomping!
Thanks for choosing me, T-Rex!
A RETURN TO EARTH!
Let's do that again sometime!
I concede it easily!
A NEW DAY DAWNS...
Now, where is my wallet?
OH SHIT!
IT IS ON THE MOON

transcription.title: Kangaroo Kicking Record

panel.line: FOUR YEARS AGO:
Today is a good day I think for being remembered! My lovely visage, callipygian frame, startlingly awesome calves and charming smile will yet go down in history! And how will I be immortalized?
I will be immortalized by kicking an evil kangaroo one thousand times. Right in the bum!

And YEAH, kicking a kangaroo in the bum has PROBABLY been done before, but never one thousand times! That's the secret to immortality: pick a direction and go SO FAR OUT in it that anyone who points to you will have to say, "Here, this is as far as anyone needs to go." Then, hey presto, you're immortalized! You're the dude who kicked an evil kangaroo as often as evil kangaroos could ever need be kicked- probably more often, actually.
So you're going for recordbook immortality?
Crazy utahraptor!!
I'm going for STUNT immortality. I'll just keep kicking that kangaroo until even if somebody wanted to catch up, they'd look at my record and say "Well, THAT'S totally not worth doing".
I guess, if that's how you want to spend your life.
IT APPARENTLY IS
FOUR YEARS LATER:
Aw shoot, I was supposed to be kicking kangaroos all this time!
LOOKS LIKE PEOPLE WILL JUST REMEMBER YOU FOR TALKING A BIG GAME MY FRIEND
I will take what I can get!!

transcription.title: it's called 'life of crime' and it's extremely excellent. you should buy one.

panel.line: I've thought of the best story! Oh goodness. This story will make me RICH. It will make me PRIME MINISTER of being rich. I will be awarded a doctorate in APPLIED RICHOLOGY.
I can only hope the world is ready for it!

So BASICALLY in the story there's all this build up about this kid whose parents named her Crime and how she grows into her name and becomes this big arch-criminal! The cops are powerless to stop her, even the really really good ones. ESPECIALLY the really really good ones. Anyway it's narrated in the third person and at the end of the book Crime goes out on a few dates with the narrator and then he abruptly stops writing because he's all cheezed at her. The end!
But - why is he all cheezed at her?
Because he always has to pay for everything!
Get it? Because CRIME DOESN'T PAY!! Listen, my story has both a hilarious twist ending and also an important message regarding the paying of crime.
Dear mental diary that everyone can hear: Utahraptor was so impressed with my book idea that he forgot how to talk!
I didn't forget how to talk! I just forgot how to shoot down your idea politely!
Utahraptor!! DON'T LISTEN TO MY DIARY!

transcription.title: as a bonus, 'life of crime' is included as an illustrative anecdote at the end of the book. STRAIGHT TO NUMBER ONE ON THE NEW YORK TIMES, BABY!

panel.line: DATING TIPS COMICS
now featuring: tips i found in this one book!
Here are some HOT TIPS FOR FIRST DATES, cats and kittens!

Okay! The first tip is this: to find out if your date is REALLY into you, all you have to do is push a salt shaker over to their side of the table! If he's interested in you, he'll pick it up and play with it, but if he's NOT interested, he'll push it back to your side. The salt shaker represents your feelings, here, okay? And playing with a salt shaker represents ROMANTIC INTENT.
That's stupid! It's semantically overloading practical actions.
See, I thought so too!

But I just thought I was crazy, because why would someone put out a dating book if all they had were sucky tips that can TOTALLY FAIL if the guy just wants saltier, and therefore tastier, fries? I could write a better dating book. IN FACT...!
Aw no, no, you don't -
MEET SOMEONE WHO DOESN'T SUCK THEN TRY KISSING THEM
A BOOK THAT WAS WRITTEN BY A MAN

transcription.title: T-REX didn't you learn anything from the beatles you don't SAY that

panel.line: It's been three days and neither "Life of Crime" nor "Meet Someone who Doesn't Suck" have made me rich. MAYBE I AM NOT THAT GREAT AN AUTHOR??
Or maybe PEOPLE are not that great an audience!
Or maybe you have to wait longer for a book to turn a profit!
Or MAYBE I should be happy that I basically wrote two books in as many days, and got them published in an afternoon, and that's kinda impressive even if they aren't selling that well so far??
Or maybe if they were selling well, you wouldn't know it yet!
THAT'S RIGHT!

Maybe I really am great, just impatient, and when I get home tonight there'll be a sales report in the mail showing how my books are now TEN TIMES MORE POPULAR THAN THE BIBLE. It would make sense, since they have like twenty times as many jokes in them!
Maybe?
OR MAYBE I JUST DIDN'T PUT MANY JOKES IN THE BIBLE BECAUSE OF TRANSLATION ISSUES.
Hey everyone! You know what needs more jokes? ONLY EVERY RELIGIOUS TEXT EVER!!
AW MAN - NOW WHAT AM I GONNA DO WITH ALL THESE RAISED EXPECTATIONS

transcription.title: t-rex is brushing his hands together in the last panel, in the way that one is inclined to do when one has solved a problem Once And For All

panel.line: Alright! Time to start some INTERNET BUSINESSES.
For profits!
SOON:
Ladies and gentlemen, I give you: easydudes.com!
It's an easy way for you to meet new dudes! If you move to a new town and want to meet some dudes then you can go to the site and then you can meet some. On the COMPUTER!
It sounds a little more like a service to hook people up with sexually permissive and sexually available dudes, T-Rex!
Drat! It DOES. Another brilliant idea ruined by a hilarious double entendre.
SOON:
Okay, so my new idea is to give the homeless access to mail, email, and a phone number!
Nice!
It can be hard for the homeless to get jobs when they can't provide callback information, so this will be a useful service. Good show, T-Rex!
Yes, thank you! I think the world will be altered positively by BumAccess4All Dot Net.
SOON:
There! Now I've got a certificate from the mayor that says I'm not allowed to name anything ever!
THAT should finally straighten up some things around here!

transcription.title: being a founder of modern philosophy is nothing but ess tea arr ee ess ess

panel.line: Descartes was a dude who wrote "Cogito ergo sum" which means "I think, therefore I am". PRETTY NEAT, cats and kittens!
But also...PRETTY FLAWED??

The whole deal with "I think, therefore I am" is that Descartes is all "DAAAAAAMN, I can't be sure of ANYTHING! My senses are flawed. All I know for sure is I keep STRESSIN' about this stuff!" and then his girlfriend is all "If you're so hung up on this then you must exist, huh baby?" and Descartes is all "Yes. That is true. I will write this down in Latin."
That is how it went down.
So what's the problem, besides your unnecessary storytelling?
Descartes' girlfriend!

She's making a huge logical leap! It's indisputible that thinking is going on, right, but we don't know for sure that Descartes is doing the thinking! All we know for sure is that thinking is going on.
I agree!
R-Really?
Yeah! You can't have thinking in a vacuum, so SOMETHING must exist if there's thinking going on...
T-Rex " Utahraptor: ...but to attribute that thinking to yourself just because you're aware of it is an awful big leap for a skeptic to make!
OH MY GOODNESS HOW DID WE JUST DO THAT

transcription.title: dog breederies are where you get dog breeders from. i shouldn't have to tell you this?

panel.line: Here are some things that DEFINITELY won't fit into my mouth. I tried! They won't fit.
First off: dog breederies, solar panel processing plants, and giant cubes!

Also: twenty cars on a stick. Sound stages, every library (individually AND en masse), medium-sized cubes that are still pretty big, lakes, beer-flavoured lakes, and beer-flavoured lakes in Minnesota.
I know for a fact that on e of those doesn't exist, T-Rex!
Doesn't exist in my mouth, that is!! Because it's too big?
Not much to talk about today, huh?
What? There's plenty to talk about!

It's just, YESTERDAY you had some neat ideas about knowledge and existence, and today you're all "here are some things that don't fit in my big ol' mouth" and your TOTALLY LYING about trying them; I can tell.
They dovetail together nicely.
I don't see how!
T-REX EXPLAINS:
Ah, that makes perfect sense! Thanks, T-Rex! Now I know how digital timers work.
You're welcome!
Now, HERE'S how putting the things in my mouth ties in with existence. . .

the end

transcription.title: will t-rex wear these glasses tomorrow? SPOILER ALERT: he will probably have buyer's regret, but will still be liable to bust them out whenever he's nostalgic for 2004, OR for new year's eve 2003.

panel.line: I went to the optometrist AGAIN last night, and AGAIN she said I might need to get nerd goggles!
(She called them "glasses" but you can tell she was thinking "nerd goggles"!)

The PROBLEM is that I define myself in terms of not having glasses! People are always "Oh. You're lookng for T-Rex? He's the green tyrannosaurus rex over there! You'll be able to spot him because he's so not wearing glasses."
Aw, I think you'd look cute in them! I also think you can turn this around and make glasses your thing, you know?
Narrator :SHORTLY THEREAFTER .
Maybe Dromiceiomimus is right!
She usually is!
I COULD get some pretty kick-ass glasses. Like glasses that say "WARNING: AWESOME DUDE" on them! OOH, or horn-rimmed 60s housewife glasses! Sweetness!
You'll have to wear them every day, so maybe you'll, um, want to see how they look before you commit?
A FEW DAYS LATER:
I'm here to pick up my prescription "Happy New year 2004" glasses! They have a plastic "2" on one side and a "4" on the other.
Optometrist Clerk: Sir, you have made an unforgettable choice.
I like you too, optometrist clerk!

transcription.title: onanism: a show of vocabulary descends into a masturbation joke

panel.line: Here is a list of adjectives I would like to have chosen when describing me!
1) "Sated"!
Second on the list: "alluring"! followed closely by "stompin'"!
Fourth: "Callipygian", pronounced "kal-lip-pee-je-en" - adj: "having beautifully proportioned buttocks!
i.e.: Me
5) "Magnanimous", which is-
Wait, aren't you missing one?
Which?
"Onanistic"?
I know what that means!!

transcription.title: if i had a friend who was a rock star you could rename my comic to 'PASSIVE AGGRESSIVE DINOSAUR COMICS'. but i don't! or if i did i'm sure he'd be cool!

panel.line: MEANWHILE, IN THE UNIVERSE WHERE T-REX IS A PROFESSIONAL SINGER:
Rock star!
ROCK STAR
I'm a totally cool rock star!

That's still awesome, right? It seems that 10 years ago people were more into rock stars and being rock stars than they are now. But I am a rock star and it is my job to sing rock songs on stage and in CD players!!
Do your other rock star friends talk like that? Do they reference themselves as "cool rock star[s]"?
Sometimes we do, Dromiceiomimus. BETWEEN ROCK SONGS, THAT IS!!
Hey, how come we never get to meet your rock star friends?
Well - um...
Are you ASHAMED of us, T-Rex?
No! They're just different people! You wouldn't get along. They like rocking and you -
I like rocking!
But in DIFFERENT WAYS.
Utahraptor, I've got to go practice rocking out now, but can we talk about this tonight?
Utahraptor [offscreen]: No! You're being a jerk!
Utahraptor! I'm super late for rocking out practice, okay?
I'm gonna need you to respect the rock, okay?

transcription.title: the prince of zombie whales

panel.line: I have some bad news: zombies are in danger of becoming old hat! It's TRUE. But I have a solution to make them interesting again: all you need is stories where not just people but ANIMALS become undead!
Zombie whales!
But better than that: zombie BIRDS.
Didn't Hitchcock make a movie about that?
Upon inspection: basically? The birds DID want to eat people in his movie. But that's a scary concept, right? Birds hungering for flesh is bad news for everyone!
It's, uh, it's especially bad for fleshy dudes.
You're dancing around the REAL threat here, T-Rex: ZOMBIE MOSQUITOES.
OH
MY
GOD
You're right! The infection would spread quickly and nearly invisibly! And mosquitoes already want blood, so it's not like they need THAT much encouragement to become zombies. Man!
I guess we can only hope that the insect kingdom never becomes zombified?
I guess so!!
28 DAYS LATER:
Off-panel: Save us! Save us from the zombie butterflies!
WEAAAAAAAK

transcription.title: finally this spot was meant as an archive title but i mostly use it to talk about how many showers i've had today (wednesday, so far: one and one half)

panel.line: Hello Morris! How are you today?
Morris: oh hello there t-rex! it's super nice to see a friendly face today
It's nice to see you too, Morris!

Morris: aw shucks t-rex, you're a real good friend, you know that? a real good friend. anyway, you should be extra careful not to eat me today or anything because i guess i got turned into a zombie last night! today has definitely had its share of challenges for me, huh
What?! Seriously?
Morris: yeah! and i dunno what i did wrong because i went to bed like normal last night but when i woke up in the morning i had zombie disease! so it was real embarrassing

Morris:but don't worry, i'm not going to turn you guys into zombies too! i wouldn't be a very good friend if i did that, and the book i got at the centre says that being a good friend is awful important!
Morris:i always try to be a good friend, even though things pretty often don't work out very well for me in the end
Aw, Morris! You don't look very undead to me!

Morris: aw, that probably just means i've messed up somewhere again. the problem is that i'm not real good at biting people, you know? and biting people is all zombies do! i didn't know, but being a zombie is an awful hassle
I'm pretty sure you're not actually undead, Morris! Normally zombies can't talk.
Yeah, or work on their Life Challenges! I think you're FINE.
Morris: you mean i'm doing that wrong too? oh goodness, i must be the worst zombie going. plus that book i got from the centre is way overdue!
It's not too late to return it, Morris!
Morris: but i promised the staff there that i'd be extra certain to return it on time!
Morris: i guess i'm probably off your christmas card list this year, huh t-rex

transcription.title: since pi is universal, any sufficiently-advance alien culture probably has a similar joke to feynman's about pi. it is a Universal Joke. that's nuts!

panel.line: I am jealous of physicist RICHARD FEYNMAN.
Aaaand here's why!

Dude made a joke about the 762nd decimal place of pi! At that point, there's a sequence of six nines in a row, and his joke was that he'd like to memorize pi up to that point, so that when reciting he could end with "9, 9, 9, 9, 9, 9... and so on." Others had noticed it before FEYNMAN was the first to make a joke about it, and now his joke is encoded into the very fabric of the universe!
And that makes you irrationally jealous?
Hells yes!
Feynman has a JOKE encoded into pi - transcendental immortality in the circumference of a circle! That's something for the ol' resume, eh?
I guess!
I'm gonna make my own universal constant joke now, and I'm gonna need you to tell people about it.

So! Why do people start getting afraid at the 2501st digit of e? Because 7 8 9! There's a sequence of "789" that starts there, and it sounds like "seven ate nine"! This is definitely called "T-Rex's Hilarious e joke", okay?

transcription.title: saying that is like unwrapping the paper on the present that is old age

panel.line: Narrator : T-REX AS AN OLD MAN COMICS
Guys, I'm still the same T-Rex I always was!
I'm even pretty well preserved: check it out, Dromiceiomimus! Barely any wrinkles!
Domiceiomimus: That's nice, T-Rex.
Also I've got my trademark "nice calves" and "young smile". I'm so old! AND YET, I'm so sexy!
Utharaptor: Hey, you know what's rad? Old dudes not talking about how sexy they are.
I'm young at heart!
I just don't want to be one of those guys who let's being old be - all they do, you know? Being old is at best incidental to what I do, and what I do is BE TOTALLY RAD.
And totally self aggrandizing.
And that! In between radness! My point is: I'm not old.
BUT SECRETELY, WHEN T-REX IS HOME ALONE:
T-Rex : Gosh darn it! If these rappers spoke more slowly, we'd ALL be able to understand what they're saying.

transcription.title: deleted dialogue had utahraptor saying 'my real objection is that by stringing together all these separate sentences with semicolons, you're really missing the spirit of the exercise, aren't you?' and then t-rex saying 'you forget though that Semicolons;

panel.line: WHAT IS THE BEST SENTENCE IN THE ENGLISH LANGUAGE COMICS
"I love you"!
No, too easy. Um - "I love you, AND ALSO, how about all these dollars?"
How about "We have cured all diseases!"?
No good, unless it's followed by "also, we've found new places for everyone to live comfortably; and hey, guess what: they're sweet new planets and we get there on starships, like from TV!"
I would have thought you'd choose something closer to "And THAT'S why they call me the widowmaker".
That IS good!
How about "Ladies! There's enough T-Rex to go around!"
It sounds a little like there's a bunch of female cannibals eating you.
Okay. "Ladies! There's enough T-Rex to go around... FOR SEXUAL CONGRESS!"
HEY! HERE'S THE ONE TIME T-REX EVER SAYS THAT SENTENCE:
Ladies! There's enough T-Rex to go around... FOR SEXUAL CONGRESS!
Dudes: We're just a regular congress!
Dudes: Also, we're dudes!
Dudes: Also... PROCEED

transcription.title: the last two sentences in this comic have never been said together before, until now. i will bet fifty cents on it.

panel.line: WHAT IS THE WORST SENTENCE IN THE ENGLISH LANGUAGE COMICS
"Your mouth is full of cockroaches: many of them are dead, but those that aren't yet are throwing up on you, and each other."
SECONDS LATER:
I'm sorry, everyone within the sound of my voice! That was disgusting!
I didn't mean for that to be as gross as it was. I should have went with "I never loved you!". That's pretty bad, eh?
Can cockroaches throw up? I think I read somewhere that they can't throw up.
I think you're thinking of rats.
Ah, that's right.
So, I guess we're not that into the "worst sentence ever" thing?
No, no, we're into it!
Here: How about "Everyone else on the planet is dead, and you will die only when you've fully mourned each and every one."
That's not bad! That's immortality for the self-centered!
HERE'S THE ONE TIME T-REX EVER SAYS THAT SENTENCE:
Excuse me, sexual congress? Everyone else on the planet is dead, and you'll only die when you've fully mourned each and every one!
Sexual Congress: That's terrible!
Sexual Congress: Guys, stop sexing me for a minute!! I need to talk to this dinosaur.

transcription.title: it's not actually his gun. chekhov, i mean. it's metaphorical. anyway.

panel.line: Chekhov's gun is when you have something conspicuously introduced early on in the story, but which doesn't become important until later on! It happens whenever Shakespeare loudly mentions how he loves Pop Tarts, and later he eats a bunch of Pop Tarts!
LITERARY TECHNIQUE COMICS
today's technique: CHEKHOV'S GUN

It comes from this playwright Chekhov, who said that if you have a gun on the stage in the first act of a play, it had better be fired by the third! It's been used to sustain interest since forever: James Bond often gets a bunch of gadgets at the beginning of his movie which he'll use later on, and even Perseus got gadgets from the GODS to kill Medusa with! It's the same idea, only Bond's better because he has more explosions. Looks like you lose, Perseus!!
So if you have Bond getting gadgets that he doesn't use, that's not Chekhov's Gun?
Nope!
That's just FRUSTRATED EXPECTATIONS. Honestly, why give James Bond a gun that shoots piranhas if he's never going to fire it? People truly want to see that in action. Also: guns that shoot chainsaws.
I'd like to see your Bond movie.
I WOULD TOO, darn it.
MEANWHILE, IN TUDOR ENGLAND!
Shakespeare, which is better: a gun that shoots chainsaws, or a gun that shoots EVEN BIGGER GUNS?
Shakespeare?
Aw, come on! There's strawberry frosting all over "As You Like It"!

transcription.title: i don't own any stock in nintendo, but that's only because i don't like to mix money with friendship.

panel.line: I am not a dude who loves big companies.
...Sometimes I like their products?

But I don't feel chummy with Microsoft, or that Sony is going to come over, eat pizza with me, and talk about the women he likes! No. Sony is going to come over, ruffle through my CD collection, then call the cops on his cell phone. Sony is going to write swears on my bathroom mirror with lipstick and blame it on Nestl?.
SONY is going to be stone cold sober the entire time.
But let me guess: there's one big company you really like?
There is indeed!!
NINTENDO. I guess they got me when I was young an uncritical, but I really LIKE them, you know? When they do well, I seriously think, "Aw, that's nice. Good for them!"
When multinationals do well, I usually feel like that's bad news for me.
Me too! But not with Nintendo!
You know what would go down if Nintendo came over? I'd sat "Oh hello, Nintendo! It's so nice to see you again!"
"Aw shucks! I guess it IS true that you're never too old to hug, Nintendo!"
"Nintendo, I just... I JUST WISH I HAD A SISTER YOU COULD MARRY."

transcription.title: profound philosophical questions vs the story of how the keys were found

panel.line: I have felt reflective of late...
Today is a good day I think for asking profound philosophical questions!
Beginning with the most modest: why am I here?
What is the purpose of my life?
Is it true that the only questions worth asking are those that cannot be answered?
Is there any greater meaning - to anything?
Yes!
There is?! What is it?!
Huh? Oh, no - I was just saying "Yes!" because I was remembering how I felt this morning when I found my keys!
W-what?
Yeah, I thought the were lost!
But I found them!
They were on top of the fridge!
I don't care!!

transcription.title: my freezer is ALSO dying a slow death! TORONTO PEOPLE: meat party tomorrow night?? maybe even tonight. i'll be in touch!

panel.line: EIGHTEEN HOURS AGO.
Aw damn! My freezer is broken!
SEVENTEEN HOURS AGO.

So do you want to come over for a meat party, Dromiceiomimus? I had my freezer stuffed with meat and it's all thawing now. The chicken's got to be cooked and I figure there's more than enough to go around! I've also got steaks AND pork chops and tons more.
Meat party!
MEAT PARTY!!
TWELVE HOURS AGO.
This meat is extremely delicious!
I know it!!
Never have I tasted the flesh of SO MANY animals in so short a time period.
I only wish I'd frozen lobsters!
Next time, I guess!
THE PRESENT
Four hundred dollars for a new freezer?
BULL
SHIT

transcription.title: if i had three wishes bequeathed to me, don't you know exactly what they would be

panel.line: the dinosaur comic players answer: WHAT WOULD YOU DO IF YOU HAD THREE WISHES
Wow, three wishes!
Nothing wrong with that!
I think I would wish that everyone would be happy forever

But you know how wishes are, Dromiceiomimus - they always end up with IRONIC and UNEXPECTEDLY NEGATIVE consequences. It's the nature of the beast! We'd probably end up mindless but technically "happy".
I'd use my other two wishes as damage control, T-Rex
What would you do with your wishes?
You know what?
I think I'd hold off on them. I'd like to go through life with the special knowledge that worse comes to worst, I could always wish for a problem to be solved.
Wow, that's an unexpectedly mature response. I figured you'd wish for "happy women with steaks" or something!
Aw MAN! Best wish ever?
[[T-Rex holding a steak in a thought bubble]]
Women: t-rex, these steaks are starting to make us sad

transcription.title: utahraptor's original spy name was 'agent orange'

panel.line: MODERN STENOGRAPHY
Guys stenography is so awesome!
I AM NOT EVEN JOKING.

It is the technology (and art!) of concealing messages from people. With stenography you can pass around SECRET MESSAGES, and nobody except for you and the target will even know the message is there! FOR EXAMPLE: digital photography! Pictures use bytes to represent colour data, right? So all you do is use the least significant bit of each byte as your payload, and tada! Instant hidden information in any old image!
But that alters the image, dear friend!
TRUE. But only a little!
Colours change to just a slightly different shade of the same colour. The naked eye won't see anything, and it'll really only be detected if you've got the original image to compare with!
It's too bad we don't have any secret messages to send.
Yes... TOO BAD INDEED.
MEANWHILE, IN THE UNIVERSE WHERE T-REX AND UTAHRAPTOR ARE SUPERSPIES:
Sir: It says here that you and Agent U just surprise each other with stenographic images of swear words all day long.
Sir! I don't understand!!
It is extremely hilarious!

panel.line: I saw the coolest fight on TV last night! It was between two shiny anthropomorphic robots. One had a metal cowboy hat.

It's just - I think I'm beginning to be in the minority here, but "decimated" means "destroy one tenth". It comes from the Roman army, who'd kill 1/10th of a cohort as an extreme form of punishment. Precision in language is a virtue!

I guess my dilemma is I love that we have a word for "1/10th destroyed", but I also love how awesome "decimated" sounds, but ALSO, I'm not sure how I feel about prescriptivism when I'm the victim."

Did you find any?

She may be the perfect woman for me, but that doesn't mean she's perfect for everyone!

transcription.title: all the ASL i know is self-taught from books, so i speak really slowly and probably have a horrible accent.

panel.line: My stars, am I ever enamoured with sign language. You can speak with your hands! That's amazing!
I LOVE SIGN LANGUAGE TOO
Well! Then it's settled!

I think the coolest thing about ASL, which is the sign language I know, is how you can place nouns in space. If I'm telling a story about my angry dog and my very sassy friend, I can make the sign for "dog" to my left, and "friend" to my right, and then when I want to apply adjectives to them, I just sign "angry" or "sassy" in the same physical space as the nouns! You can have nouns FLOATING AROUND YOU in conversation. How is that not the best thing EVER?
Also, many of the signs are really evocative, so they're easy to remember!
Like what?
Like - the sign for elbow is just pointing to your elbow, and the sign for child is patting the head of an imaginary child. For children you pat several heads!
Neat!
I know!
Um - I have nothing bad to say about sign language, the end!

transcription.title: if i ever build a secret base it will be known as 'base 10'

panel.line: SOME people are used to counting in base 10, where they've got 10 digits (0 through 9). In this system, the number 24 means twenty-four things!
But this is not the only way.

24 in base 10 ACTUALLY means "two tens and four ones", which adds up to twenty-four. But if we were counting in base 5, for instance - where the only numbers we have are from 0 to 4 - then 24 would mean "two FIVES and four ones" - in other words, fourteen! We call base 10 "base 10" because every number in it can be multiplied by 10 by adding a zero to the end. In base 5, added zeros multiply by 5!
And there's bases that go higher, too!
You're right. You can use any base.
In base 16, "24" would mean "2 sixteens and four ones", or 36! And we can use letters (A-F) to represent the digits ten to fifteen, like "3A", which means 58!
All this and more is possible with alternative base systems!
LATER:
WHAT'S WRONG WITH ME?
I STILL REALLY WISH DROMICEIOMIMUS HAD BROUGHT ME BACK SOMETHING FROM AUSTRALASIA

transcription.title: THE AMAZING TECHNICAL ORIGINS OF WORDS

panel.line: THE AMAZING TECHNICAL ORIGINS OF WORDS
prepare yourself for a journey into adventure
and WORDS
today's word: "TOTALLED:
If you trash something, you might say, "Daaamn! I just totalled my own legs!!"
This conveys the meaning of "Curses. I have destroyed my walkin' parts."
Indeed!! But that slang actually comes from the insurance industry: there, if a car is damaged, and the cost of repairs is greater than the TOTAL value of the vehicle, then it's said to be totalled!
Neat! Are there other slang words that have an origin in technical writing?
YES, my friend. OH YES.
For example, "idiot", "moron", and "imbecile" were once terms used by psychologists to denote various degrees of developmental delay. Neutral terms, if you can believe that!
I find that hard to believe!
And yet, you must! ACTUALLY, "idiot" began life in ancient Greece -
Idiot: NO I DIDN'T
. . . in ancient Greece, as a term referring to people who are self-interested to the point of being anti-social. THAT WAS WHAT I WAS GOING TO SAY. We weren't talking about you, Idiot!

But T-Rex, there's a huge number of societal and cultural factors to consider. For example, people SANG over music, and it's not that big a step from rap. I'm sure there where people experimenting in that direction throughout history, and it just didn't catch on for a variety of reasons.

panel.line: Time for me to invent a new emotion! This emotion is for when you're nostalgic for a time you were never alive in, like when a chick is nostalgic for a time of pirates! Or, when a dude misses being a 16th century courtesan.

panel.line: I have other interests beyond sex! For example I am interested in...
... the Capgras delusion!

The Capgras delusion occurs when someone believes that someone close to them - a dear friend, spouse, or family member - has been replaced by an identical-looking duplicate! What seems to happen is that the automatic EMOTIONAL responses to seeing someone familiar one day stop happening, so when they meet their loved one, they have an intense feeling of something being OFF about them. They don't feel like they normally do!
And that means they believe they've been replaced by a duplicate?
Some of the time!

Not everyone leaps from that feeling to "they've been replaced", but some do, and that's the Capgras delusion! There's variants where people feel that their pets have been replaced, or their shoes, or things like that.
It's probably really terrifying and frustrating that nobody is willing to believe you.

I can imagine! What's neat though is that it's sometimes based on VISUAL recognition, so that affected person will be fine talking to their loved ones on the phone! It makes me glad I don't have any mental illnesses.

panel.line: ISLAND DWARFISM COMICS
Island dwarfism is BASICALLY the best form of evolution ever.
It's SO CUTE!

Basically, the idea is that if a species gets to an island and is then isolated, it can evolve on its own, apart from what's happening on the rest of the planet. And if food supplies are limited, as they often are on islands, smaller individuals have an evolutionary advantage since they need less food to live! If the larger species survives at all, it usually survives by shrinking.
How much shrinkage are we talking about here?
Oh my goodness, Utahraptor, you have no idea!
You can get dwarf ELEPHANTS. Tiny little elephants with tiny little tusks!
Yeah, but how tin-
Is a 98% reduction in mass tiny enough for you? Utahraptor. THEY ARE THE MAYORS OF TINY TOWNE.
EARLIER:
Mr. Tusks: Hullo T-Rex, my name is "Mr. Tusks" and I'm a tiny elephant! Someone left me on this island for too long.
Oh my goodness, Mr. Tusks! Are you the MAYOR of Tiny Towne?
Mr. Tusks: vice-mayor

transcription.title: it's because you love that tiny joke, t-rex, no matter how many times you hear it. but i do too so we're cool!

panel.line: Island gigantism is a pretty okay form of evolution.
It's okay.
ISLAND GIGANTISM COMICS

So what happens here is you've got a population that's so isolated on an island, but you have plenty of food and no predators! So smaller animals like birds and rodents that normal had to stay tiny to avoid being eaten are free from that constraint, and so they can evolve to be enormous. Giant turtles! Giant cockroaches! Giant birds! The dodo started out as a pigeon.
And now, all the dodos are dead!
And now, all the dodos are dead.

That's depressing, eh? It's the problem with island gigantism: as soon as we discover the island, we tend to either eat all the animals ourselves, or introduce new predators that find these trusting giants to be EASY PICKINS.
Yep! It's too bad.
THAT EVENING:
Mr Tusks, do you ever get depressed thinking about all the animals we've made extinct?
Mr Tusks: I guess I get a... TINY bit depressed, T-Rex!
Oh, Mr. Tusks! how do you always know just what to say?

panel.line: Okay, okay, so we can modify our personality, right? We're not the same people we were when we were six years old, and part of that has to be controlled by us.
We make New Year's Resolutions for a reason!

So we've got a self-modifying system: we examine our personality, determine things we don't like, and try to make them better. But how do we decide what we don't like? Our personality must feed into that process too! So you've got this feedback loop that goes all the way back to when we were born and started making decisions. And it seems to me that if you changed just a tiny thing early on, you could get a completely different adult down the road!
Sensitive dependence on initial conditions! It's chaos theory applied to personalities, right?
Right!

Okay, some issues off just the top of my head: you haven't proven your assumption of control (conscious or otherwise) over personality, you seem to assume that babies are born as a blank slate with no initial personality, you leave the idea of "personality" pretty ill defined for something so central to your argument, and you haven't shown that altering behaviour (viz., Resolutions) is the same as altering personality.

panel.line: SLANG FOR TEENS
Teens! Are you interested in slang?

Here is some handy slang for you, teens! "Bad" means "good". For example, "that rock concert was BAD!" Further, "bogus" means "bad", but these aren't transitive. Something that's bogus isn't good. "Bodacious" means "good", but these aren't symmetric either. A salad might be bodacious if it's exceptional, though.

panel.line: Text: A MYSTERY STORY

Text: Once upon a time there was guy who "knocked over" (broke into) a bank and stole some money. Who did it? It was a mystery. Nobody knew the answer. They all asked each other who "knocked over" the bank but nobody knew for sure.
Text: It was this guy. He did it. T-Rex. This guy.

Text: But the bank was evil so it was okay to steal from it. It was justified. It's like if you stole from Hitler. Would that be so bad? Hitler would be mad if you stole from him. But, he's Hitler. There are a lot of moral grey areas in mystery stories.
Text: Most banks aren't even evil but this one was pretty bad. Imagine the worst things you can do. I will tell you right now that this bank did them five times before breakfast.
Text: There was a cop called Utahraptor who saw T-Rex and he chased him on foot. It was exciting. Where would the chase lead to now?

Text: The chase was on motorbikes for a while and then on skateboards. Then they chased on hang gliders. A bystander told his wife it was the best chase ever and she knew it was true. They were chasing on foot again when it ended. Utahraptor arrested T-Rex, but T-Rex explained how the bank was evil. The cop thought now I am torn between the law and what I believe is right. What do I do now! Utahraptor let T-Rex go with a warning. T-Rex said thanks I have learned my lesson. The mystery was solved, except for one part: where would the spirit of adventure take T-Rex next??
So? What do you think, Pulitzer Prize-winning author Michael Chabon?
Michael Chabon: I asked you to proofread a chapter, not to substitute your own retarded story!
I don't think you should use the word "retarded" like that, Michael Chabon.

panel.line: T-REX THE TALKING DINOSAUR IN:
Is it true that the content of our thoughts - their very meaning - is determined, at least in part, by our environment?
SEMANTIC EXTERNALISM COMICS

Okay, suppose I think "I love chocochops", which are of course delicious chocolate pork chops with a real pork chop bone. And say there's a twin Earth, completely identical - EXCEPT that there, chocochops have a different chemical makeup, but taste and look the same! If my twin thinks "I love chocochops", he's actually referring to the one with CRAZY CHEMICALS, while when I think that, I'm referring to a chemically different object. The environment determines our semantics!
Ah, the famous "Twin Earth" thought experiment of Hilary Putnam!
SOMEONE CAME UP WITH IT FIRST?

Yeah, only his example was about water having a different composition on Twin Earth, instead of those hauntingly stupid chocochops you invented. The point is that both thinkers have the exact same mental state but are saying different things, and the environment is responsible for meaning there.
EPILOGUE: A FEW DAYS LATER, T-REX CALLS HIS GRANDMOTHER.
But I don't mention anything about semantic externalism!
Sometimes I like to call her just to say hello

transcription.title: friday fun verificationism comics!

panel.line: In verificationism, a sentence has to be verifiably true (or false!) for it to be meaningful. Not bad, guys! I think this is one philosophy that is verifiably REASONABLE.
So that's it for arguing about religion! Can't verify faith!

In fact, that's it for a lot of debate, because how can you argue FACTS? Most verificationist arguments must end with the parties involved looking things up in an encyclopaedia together and then firmly shaking hands.
But if they can't verify something, what do they do?
They agree that the sentence is meaningless! If it can't be checked, there's no use considering it, so it's ignored. Facts only please!!
But how does anyone know what's true?
Because... because of Science?

Come on, T-Rex, you know better! Science is about being empirically ACCURATE, which might not be the same thing as being true. Plus your senses could be lying to you, you could be a brain in a jar, etc.. If you're going to be verificationist, you're going to need a pretty impregnable definition of "truth".
Aha! But I can't VERIFY that my senses are liars, nor can I verify that I'm a brain in a jar! How does THAT taste, Utahraptor?
You can verify the science thing!
Can you just tell me how it tastes, when you put THAT in your pipe and smoke it?

transcription.title: i saved you some time there.

panel.line: If I'm going to be verificationist, I'd better figure out what it means to say that something is true! I'm going to start with... relativism!
This one is all, "Well, it's true for me!"

Guys. Come on. This is the dumbest theory of truth. This is the theory of truth that draws tattoos on itself in blue pen and then when you ask why anyone would draw a picture on their forearm of tree, with sausages, with the words "sausage tree" beneath it, it gets mad and says "You don't understand my truth!"
I'm - I'm personifying a little here but that's seriously what relativism does.
What about fascist truth, where something is true because those with power say it's true?
Again - ultra dumb!
What I want is a theory of truth that's incontrovertible. In fact, I don't want even a THEORY of truth! I want a fact of truth.
You're not going to get it! There's like 20 trillion theories, but no facts.
Oh YEAH?? We'll see about that!
TWENTY TRILLION THEORIES OF TRUTH LATER:
Well God, I guess it really just goes to show you that there's many different competing ideas about what "true" really means!
UH HUH
And THAT'S the truth!
UH HUH

transcription.title: 2 2=5 you guys

panel.line: Wait, I know some truths that are absolute: mathematical truths! How could I have been so blind?
It is a FACT that one plus one equals two!
All I need is a way to convert mathematical truths to the real world and I WILL NEVER BE WRONG AGAIN!

Um - I'm sorry to break it to you, T-Rex, but mathematical truths aren't absolute either. Math is built on a priori assumptions: you start with a few things that you assume are true and build on them! Stuff like "1+2 is the same as 2+1". Then you build up a mathematical system around that, but that doesn't mean math is true. It's just - consistent!
But... 1+2 IS the same as 2+1!
Or so you think, T-Rex!
Damn my potentially-flawed senses!

When our mathematical assumptions APPEAR to match up with reality, the results may also seem to apply - but math isn't any more "true" because of that! It's still based on unproven/unprovable assumptions. And you can actually build up systems where you decide that 1+2 does not equal 2+1, and they're just as consistent!
LATER:
Attention, everyone I've ever met and ever will meet! Never mention the "flawed senses" idea again, okay? It prevents me from knowing absolute truth.
Everyone T-Rex has ever met and ever will meet: SURE THING, T-REX!
Patrick Stewart! What are you doing here?
Patrick Stewart: um, being BORED

transcription.title: I have "gone" "too far" "down" the "rabbit hole"

panel.line: I have gone too far "down the rabbit hole" and am reduced to being sure only of my own thoughts, and even then some other chump could be projecting them into my head. To that I say: "whatEVER!"
People do fine with approximations!

So what if truth is a platonic ideal that can't be reached? I'm fine with that! When someone says to me, "T-Rex, your birthday is this Saturday," will I demand they prove it? No. I will say "wicked sweettimes" and then I would say "what did you get me" and then I would say "I bet it's so awesome" and that will be that.
Hey, your birthday really is this Saturday!
See? It's true!

OR, it's close enough to true that we all agree on it. Brains in jars don't get birthdays! This is the reality I'm living in, and if it's not real then OH WELL, at least we'll all be eating ice cream cake come Saturday. You know?
I hear you!
Voice: Hey, T-Rex! This ice cream cake is delicious!
Thanks! Don't you think it tastes like... philosophical compromise?
Voice: Only a little!
But you can hardly taste it, eh?

transcription.title: Guys, I totally know!

panel.line: What if... what if I had the BEST HOUSE EVER this Hallowe'en?
[[inside T-Rex's thought bubble]]
Guys: T-Rex! This house is SPOOK-TACULAR!
Guys, I totally know!!
I must make this dream come true! But HOW?
What if you made your house spiritually scary, T-Rex? Like, instead of a corpse, a mannequin of a woman who is realizing that she has married badly.
Not bad! And I could have a spooky tape, but instead of chainsaws and screams, I'd have the voice of a man quietly dictating memories of his youth, knowing Alzheimer's will rob him of them soon.
But these ideas won't be scary for passers-by!
Sure they will!
They need explanation! The best scares are like the best art, where you get it viscerally, without a little placard beneath it that says "OKAY. SO. WHAT'S GOING ON HERE IS ALZHEIMER'S."
Man, you just wait! Kids will be boarding the train to SCARYTOWNE at my house.
HALLOWE'EN NIGHT:
Kid: Mister, why is that man talking about when he was a kid?
Because he's got a disease that robs him of his memories, relationships and identity. It is death before death.
Oooh, what scary costumes!

Or, knowing that no matter what, you're NEVER going to win the lottery!
Also good!
I just want one little tidbit, you know?

T-REX ONE DAY YOU'RE GOING TO PUNCH AN ATTACKING BEAR IN THE SOLAR PLEXUS AND THEN HE'LL BEND OVER IN PAIN AND THEN YOU'LL ELBOW HIM IN THE BACK

transcription.title: the best non-verbal response to being dumped: the one and only slow clap

panel.line: THINGS TO SAY WHEN SOMEONE HAS BROKEN UP WITH YOU
Sometimes, someone will break up with you. Aw snaps! What do you say to THAT?
Here are some things you can say to that!
"It's okay, sweetie! I'm sure one day you'll find someone ALMOST as good as me!"
"Would you also break up with a rocket skateboard? BECAUSE THOSE WOULD BE GREAT. LIKE ME. I AM GREAT."
"You can't fire me, baby! I quit!"
"Don't you think you should have settled while you were ahead?"
"What if your next boyfriend is uglier?"

"Honestly though, I will always treasure the time we had together. I liked who I was with you - who we were together - and I hope we'll both be able to take that with us in the future. You've changed me and you're a part of who I am. I know our relationship will be different now, but I can't imagine ever not loving you."
"Oh, were we dating?"

panel.line: Cargo cults are religions that have developed during World War II in island tribal societies exposed to the West! Islanders saw planes delivering amazing and valuable cargo to the troops, and believed it to be divine.
KARGO KULT KOMICS

During the war, the islanders would see this cargo going to the troops and would grow to believe that the gods meant it for them - that the white people were just getting it sooner because of their influential rituals. And of couse, after the war ended and the troops left, the cargo stopped being dropped too.
So what happened then?
The islanders started mimicking what they'd seen the troops doing!
The result was ersatz marches, imitation airstrips and walkie talkies made out of wood and bamboo, and even torch signal flares, used to signal divine planes that never come!
Wow! It recasts Western military culture and tools as religious practice and iconography, respectively!

I know! It's CRAZY! Not in the pejorative sense, but in the more esoteric "Holy crap the Prime Directive on Star Trek was RIGHT" sense of crazy. It's a very particular sense of crazy but I'm feeling it right now!
I'm feeling it right now too, and I don't even watch nerd shows!!

panel.line: Homophones are words that SOUND the same but mean different things, like "news" and "gnus". Way to go only part way, HOMOPHONES.
Don't bother showing up to my dinner party, HOMOPHONES.

More impressive, and still invited for Yukon Potato Gnocchi, are words that are SPELT the same, but have two different meanings: words like "attribute" (to credit something to someone) and "attribute" (a property of something)! One's a noun and one's a verb and it's seriously so awesome. I cannot imagine how to perfect these words, as they are already perfect! Oh ho ho!
But are there really a lot of these words?
Utahraptor! Let's be serious!
Are you not familiar with accent? Or with addict, combine, conduct, conflict, content, and object? PERHAPS YOU'D ALSO LIKE TO SAY HELLO TO PERFECT, PRESENT, PROGRESS, REFUND, SUSPECT, AND UPSET?
Okay.
Okay. Well. They're at my dinner party tonight.
LATER THAT EVENING.

WAIT WHAT

transcription.title: custom can mean "conventional" (its our custom), but also "unique" (a custom suit)! custom, you can come to MY dinner parties anytime.

panel.line: LATE LAST NIGHT:
T-REX HAVE YOU EVER HEARD OF HOMOGRAPHIC HOMOPHONIC AUTANTONYMS
I have not!
OKAY SO HERE'S WHAT THEY'RE LIKE
THIS MORNING:
Sorry, other word classes! I have a NEW girlfriend now!

A homographic homophonic autantonym is a word that is spelt AND pronounced the same, but has two opposite and contradictory meanings! For example, I can dust a crop (adding pesticides to it), or I can dust a counter (removing dust from it)! Way to go, dust! You are a winner; you are a word that contains multitudes.
Why do we let language get like this?
Probably because we want it to be incredibly awesome?
And both "dust"s are the same part of speech there, too, so you can't use word order to determine meaning!
INDEED!

ALL YOU CAN DO is hope to use your real-world knowledge about crops and tables to figure out what's going on. And it's even worse with words like "overlook", meaning "examine" but ALSO meaning "miss noticing entirely". Can't rely on the noun there!
How come you love words that make communication difficult?
What is not to like? They're words that do their job in the most sarcastic, sullen, passive-aggressive way possible, and they totally get away with it!
I just want to pat them on the head and ruffle their hair, you know?

transcription.title: also involved: issues of privilege, fairness, respect, and whether or not its appropriate to apologize when deciding not to give money to a stranger

panel.line: So this homeless guy asked me for change yesterday.
The first thing I thought was, "Sure!"

But then I thought, well, wait, if I really want to fight homelessness, wouldn't this money be better spent on community programs that fight it, both through helping the homeless, and through political change? But then I thought, well, this guy's right here, you know, and saying that I'm going to make a donation isn't gonna cut it. And then I thought, wait, this guy looks pretty out of it- is he going to spend my money on drugs? Do I want to tacitly support his addiction?
And then you thought how prejudiced that was?
Sure did!

And then I thought, even if he is going to spend it on drugs, is it my job to deny him money? Should I go around enforcing my morality on others? And then I thought, geez man, how ridiculous am I that a guy asking for change throws me into these throes of self-doubt and analysis?
Pretty ridiculous?
Pretty ridiculous! But then I recalled Socrates "The unexamined life is not worth living" and at that point my head pretty much exploded.
Did you give the guy anything?
I gave him my change and whispered "DON'T TELL ANYONE UNTIL I CAN FIGURE US OUT"?

Want to come over for some "chai" tea?
Sure!
You and the Dromiceiomimus had dinosaur sex?!
Sure did!
And you played Scrabble without me?
Yes! Can we continue this later? I have to go babysit a little pterodactyl.
I lost the baby I was babysitting!
I'm screwed!
AND NOW, THE CONCLUSION. . .

panel.line: MEANWHILE, IN THE UNIVERSE WHERE ALL PROVERBS ARE SLIGHTLY DIFFERENT:
My bike broke because I had maintained it poorly. But you know what they say!
"200 kilotons of prevention is worth 3200 kilotons of cure!"
They also say, "An apple a day keeps the doctor in his house. Look: the doctor has no clients."
Further, T-Rex, they go on to observe that "One bad apple spreads decay to other apples stored nearby. An entire barrel can easily be ruined in this manner."
It's SO TRUE.
Hey, have you noticed how our proverbs are - a little awkward?
Now that you mention it, I have!
It's like they're all poorly-phrased versions of things that could be condensed down. Like, "You are what you ingest, figuratively, and, in a sense, literally!" It's just weird.
You'd expect that over time they'd condense down to their core meanings. But I guess that's our friggin' universe for you!
LATER, A LONG TRAIN RIDE HOME:
"If there was a singular Dickens who had to pee, I would be SO like him right now."

transcription.title: THIS COMIC DEDICATED TO NASEEM, "THE FRIEND WHO CHANGED THE TIME FOR THE EVENT BUT NEGLECTED TO UPDATE THE FACEBOOK DOT COM EVENT PAGE"

panel.line: Who was the dude sitting alone at the biggest table in a packed restaurant last night, waiting for friends who never came? It was ME!
Friiiiiig!
But it's tonight that we're all planning to meet for dinner!

I know! I got the dates confused and there I was, Mr. No Friends Who Likes To Pretend. After about 30 minutes I started smiling at people who'd look at me and make this shrugging "Friends, huh? They sure are unreliable!" gesture, which I'd then follow up with a "I have lots of friends: hand signal. Looks like this.
So you were That Guy at the restaurant!
I was! But then I started trying to own it, you know?

I ordered this big appetizer platter "for my friends when they arrive" and distributed it so there was food for everyone, slowly picking at my share while the rest went cold. It was great. I perfected this heart-breakingly hopeful glance up whenever new people came it.
Oh man!

Eventually I just stopped looking up at all, blankly staring at the chicken wing bones on my plate. Finally I ordered a piece of cake with a candle and sang "Happy birthday" to myself, quiet and soft.
The waitress gave me the cake for free!

transcription.title: the wise-cracking criminal owns a parrot who also cracks wise. they don't get along, so he leaves the parrot at home for the duration of the film.

panel.line: I have the greatest idea for a movie! I've said this before but this time it's for serious. There's this cop, right?
Right!

And he's a "by-the-books" cop who does everything "by-the-books". But one day a big crime is committed and the only guy who knows anything about it is this criminal: a criminal who is prone to cracking wise! So the cop and the criminal have to team up to stop the bad guys before they commit crimes again. And at the end they have learned to respect each other's way of life, and they hug for a while. Five stars!
Aw, T-Rex, come on. Why would a "by-the-books" cop team up with a criminal?
Um, TO SOLVE CRIMES??
But he's by the books! I don't think there's anything in the "books" about deputizing criminals to go after other criminals. Why wouldn't he just interrogate him to get the information he needs?
. . .The movie takes place on a planet where interrogation is banned.
Movie Poster Text: On a PLANET where INTERROGATION is BANNED
Movie Poster Text: One "BY THE BOOKS" COP and one WISE-CRACKING CRIMINAL have to TEAM UP to CATCH OTHER CRIMINALS

transcription.title: people in england: here in canada we find your british swears to be absolutely charming! the angrier you get the more we say, "hah hah hah, awwww."

panel.line: So Columbus discovers America, right? Or at least, he REdiscovers the continent. He discovers it for Europe. Maybe not for the first time.
Columbus popularizes the continent!

And afterwards, what happens is what cooks call the "Columbian explosion", where fruits and vegetables brought back from the new world have a profound effect on the cooking in the old one! Tomatoes and potatoes are but two of the best-rhyming examples. When people back home discovered these vegetables, they started experimenting with them and coming up with all sorts of crazy, YET DELICIOUS, dishes! The Columbian explosion was an explosion of TASTE.
And now, Italian food is basically defined by the tomato!
Exactly!

And we don't think "Irish cooking" without "potato", and South Korean food is big on Western peppers too! It must have been an exciting time, trying these new meals that nobody on the continent had ever tasted.
And they were SO GOOD, they supplemented or replaced existing cultural dishes!
It makes me wish we could have something like that, you know? I'm TIRED of the same old vegetables.
I COULD CREATE SOME NEW ONES
And I'm TIRED of God offering to create new vegetables for me.
TO THAT I CAN ONLY SAY
BOLLOCKS

transcription.title: on the plus side, this alienberry pie is OUTSTANDING.

panel.line: Okay MAYBE there were some downsides to the Columbian explosion. The old world got tomatoes and potatoes, AND corn and peanuts, AND rubber, AND cocoa, and in exchange gave the new world... lettuce?
And also horses!

And also the cholera and influenza and bubonic plague and typhoid fever, and um, smallpox. So basically the world got this explosion of new and tasty times, but also this exchange of disease, and just about every culture on Earth was affected. But what's neat is that we can look forward to the same thing if we ever encounter alien life!
Except it's unlikely that we'd be vulnerable to their diseases.
Well... MAYBE.
But we don;t know anything about alien life! Maybe they'll look just like us AND share diseases with us, but with pointier ears. And logic?
Or maybe they'll look like us, but, you know, ten times sexier. Everyone on Earth will feel bad about their bodies for the rest of time!
MEANWHILE IN THE UNIVERSE WHERE THIS HAS HAPPENED:
maybe...
maybe i should get me some clothes

transcription.title: 'We need leaders who understand technology,' muttered Amelia!

panel.line: "We Need Leaders Who Actually Understand Technology." Ahem. Amelia and Antonio Tony stood in the bedroom. They were going to have sex! This is how things looked like they were going to me, the omniscient third-person narrator: sexy times ahoy.
'We need leaders who actually understand technology,' muttered Amelia!

Antonio Tony nodded curtly, taking off his pants. It was so obvious. Amelia locked eyes with Antonio, paused, and took off her shirt. Antonio smiled appreciatively. 'There are so many bad laws passed through a misunderstanding of how computers actually work,' he thought. Amelia's breasts were pretty great. Antonio was hot too but THIS omniscient third-person narrator is into the ladies.
Writing more erotica, I see!
This one's new! It's POLITICALLY CHARGED.
"Soon Antonio and Amelia had sex and it was great. They decided they had a pretty good time. Suddenly, you find yourself agreeing... We Need Leaders Who Actually Understand Technology!"
It's written in the second person?
In parts. Isn't it great?
The book's slogan is, "Think Like Me, While You're Imagining Sex."

transcription.title: a wizard has turned you into a whale... of a good time!

panel.line: If someone says something is "a whale of a good time", I'm expecting to see some marine life.
Guys! I am not alone in this!

The phrase has been ruined bye people making the obvious stupid joke. Now it's only used by zoos featuring whales, or by dads, when then are taking their kids to visit zoos featuring whales. It's also used by marine biologists, and dads, when they are taking their kids to visit marine biologists. IT'S NOT EVEN A GOOD JOKE! You are using the word "whale" when talking about a whale. That's not comedy! That's a literal use of adjectives.
So you don't want to see marine life when someone says "a whale of a good time"?
Not always!

It should mean "a good time that is large or immense: METAPHORICALLY like a whale", but the metaphor's broken because it's always used on literal friggin' whales. "Dog-gone great" is getting there too. But Im gonna fight it, one person at a time!
Well -- good luck!
Later, on a whale-watching tour:
Whale Watcher: Wow, I'm having a WHA-
YOU ARE HAVING AN ELEPHANT OF A GOOD TIME.
Whale Watcher: You know what? I think I am!

transcription.title: never lose a baby

panel.line: Well, if there has been a moral to my life over the past few days, it has been this: never lose a baby!
Never do that!
T-REX IN
"NEVER LOSE A BABY"
Never lose a baby, because if you do, the mother will be very angry until the baby is returned!
Never lose a baby, because if you do, people likely won't trust you with babies in the future!
I've got one!
Never lose a baby, because if you do, you might be forced to pay for the loss with one of your own babies!
That's true!
So what's the lesson here, T-Rex?
Never lose a baby!

transcription.title: this is me getting up this morning: "oh boy, i wonder what i'm gonna write today?" and then this is me after writing this comic: "oh, looks like it's 'something eat something that that something'"

panel.line: Has there ever been a situation in which a tiger has eaten a penguin?
And then the penguin is all, "DANG"?
But those two animals would never meet in real life, right?

Right! So that leaves us, the dinosaurs, to introduce the two species and watch one of them get gobbled! Have we done that? Or have we been shirking our Decadent Tops of the Food Chain responsibility of Unnatural Carnivore Pairings?
I don't get why you're so interested in this!
PROBABLY because it's really interesting?

I just figure it's a pretty short list of animals that haven't been eaten by a tiger, you know? And I don't know how many people have had the pleasure of seeing something eat something that that something has never eaten before, but I'd like to be one of those people.
But penguins are so cute!
SOON:
Off-panel: Hey, who put the penguin in the tiger pit?!
Whoever he is, I bet he's handsome!
Off-panel: Aw FRIG, now the penguin has eaten the tiger!
Off-panel: THERE'S A REASON WE KEEP THEM SEPARATED, EVERYONE

panel.line: What would be the best thing for me to do tonight? As I see it, I could do the dishes, or I could mop the floors, or I GUESS that I could invent an elixir that gives me the strength of twenty men.
LATER:
Or I guess I could do all three!
THE NEXT MORNING:
And that's the amazing true story of how I invented my elixir, Dromiceiomimus.
And it really works? It gives you the strength of twenty men?
ALMOST. It actually gives me the strength of twenty girlfriends!
They're tough girlfriends.
I'm uh, I'm still not really solid on what the elixir does.
Strength! 20 girlfriends!
Yeah, I get that! So, what: the mental strength, self-confidence and I guess time-management skills intrinsic to having twenty girlfriends?
No. What? I don't know how to explain it better. If twenty girlfriends can lift up a car then I can lift up that car too.

Doug: When he arises, inform him his friend Doug would have words with him.

BACKSTORY: UTAHRAPTOR WAS CRASHING ON THE COUCH LAST NIGHT BECAUSE IT WAS LATE AND HE DIDN'T WANT TO TAKE A CAB HOME. ALSO, DOUG KNEW ABOUT THIS. DOUG IS A FRIEND OF UTAHRAPTOR'S. LATER:
I don't see why you're making fun of Doug!
He talks like a 1920s villain!

So, whatever! He talks like he's a 1920s serial villain. We all have idiolects. For example, you're a man who says "dude" and "awsome" in places where he could instead simply say "chap" and "I say, that's quite agreeable."
Yeah, but chap, you know what I don't say?
I don't say, "He slumbers still? Alack! One thousand curses! When the Sandman's spell at last lies vanquished at his feet, give him good heed: Doug has come calling."

transcription.title: a deleted line had t-rex explaining how television is like combination vision-o-vision and audi-o-vision. then *I* was gonna say, "car fans: audi-o-vision is not what you think it is, and you 'audi' be less obsessed about cars."

panel.line: Oh man! I've just had an elephant of a good idea!
TOUCH-o-vision!
Smell-o-vision has been tried, and vision and hearing are taken care of, but two senses remain yet untapped! Taste-o-vision sounds disgusting, but - there's so much potential for touch-o-vision!
Like what?
Like it's a boxing movie, and whenever the underdog hero gets punched, you get punched! You'd start to think, "MAN, I hope that guy wins! Then I'd get punched less!"
This - you know this is a terrible idea, right?
I admit only that there are issues.
Issues! You're building a robotic punching machine that can punch a whole room of people at once! What if the elderly were in the audience? What if it was calibrated wrong and punched through a guy?
Ooh, what if? What if? Here's a what if for you: WHAT IF I MAKE A MILLION DOLLARS?
TESTING THE PUNCHING MACHINE:
Ow! What the hell, Punchbot?
Punchbot: ERROR 14: I LIKE PUNCHING

transcription.title: matt wrote in yesterday to ask if punchbot was programmed via punchcards. heck yes he is!

panel.line: I know it's terrible, and I know many people are like this. But I can't deny it any longer! I am that guy!
I am that guy who goes to stand up comedy and thinks, "MAN, I could TOTALLY do that!"
And I know the best comics just make it look easy and I know it's hard to get a room full of strangers to laugh, but NEVERTHELESS, I am utterly convinced that I could do it.
So then, do it T-Rex! Write some material, sign up for an amateur night, and do it!
You know what? I will!
Are you serious? You're serious about this?
Yep!
Then count me in too. I've always kinda wanted to try that, and even if we bomb, it will at least be fun!
Exactly! And if we get some friends in the audience, at least THEY can laugh.
T-Rex and Utahraptor: We've got to go write some material!
FOR THE NEXT THREE WEEKS:
T-Rex's thoughts: Huh! Instead of writing "I rode a horse", I wrote "I wrode a horse"!
T-Rex's thoughts: I COULD USE THIS IN MY ACT.

transcription.title: And he actually IS an alcoholic!

panel.line: You know what would be the worst? Meeting someone who was ACTUALLY NAMED "Al Coholic".
And he actually IS an alcoholic!

And he hasn't changed his name and he hates it and he drinks all the time. And everyone laughs when they hear his name, and then they get to know him and discover his illness and they feel awful. They begin to wonder if their laughter makes him drink.
But why wouldn't he just go by "Albert"? Or "Alberto"?
Maybe he's searching for an answer to that question, Dromiceiomimus... at the bottom of a bottle.
T-Rex, come on, this is ultra dumb.
I'm just saying! It would be the worst.

If you were his friend you'd always say "Come on Al, stop drinking, change your name. At least go by your middle name." And then he'd take a swig from the bottle, wipe his mouth with the back of his hand, and tell you his middle name is "Choc".
And then he'd eat a chocolate?
He probably would! Man!
Poor Al!
I've never felt worse for inventing someone!

transcription.title: no more sunday-afternoon calls from mom, asking how astronaut school applications are going

panel.line: I am a guy who likes to keep his hopes and dreams SECRET. This is because, if I fail to achieve them, then only I know that I screwed up!
Works for me!

It's like, say I tell everyone I want to be an astronaut, right? And now it's 20 years later and I'm not an astronaut and it's some stupid "what have you done with your life" reunion and everyone's like "HEY T-REX, HOW'S THE ASTRONAUT LIFESTYLE? IS IT - IS IT PRETTY ACHIEVEABLE?"
I'd much rather they say, "What did T-Rex say he wanted to be? I can't recall! I bet it's what he is now, though."
But everyone wanted to be an astronaut!
Perhaps!
But not everyone wanted to, say, be in a committed relationship and own a house before they were 25.
Hah! You wanted that?
SEE? SEE? This is why I keep my hopes and dreams to myself.
SECRETLY

panel.line: Hypothesis: all movie titles can be made better by the addition of the word "Friggin'".
Proff by selected examples!
Back To The Friggin' Future!
Bill And Ted's Excellent Friggin' Adventure; The Ten Friggin' Commandments; Honey, I Shrunk The Friggin' Kids!
What about Gone With The Friggin' Wind, Casa-Friggin'-Blanca, and It's A Friggin' Wonderful Life?
Some Like It Friggin' Hot?
Come on, this is all the same joke!
DENIED!

There is nuance, subtlety in the placement of the Friggin'. Contrast and compare The Friggin' Sound of Music; Guess Who's Coming to Friggin' Dinner; Big Friggin' Trouble in Little Friggin' China; and Yes, Virginia, There Is A Friggin' Santa Claus.
Okay, I think I get it!
Pride and Friggin' Prejudice.
Right on!
Look Who's Friggin' Talking!
Yes!!
FRIGGIN' THE GHOSTBUSTERS!
...You're doing it wrong.

panel.line: I have recently acquired some snake oil, and it has inspired me to compile a list of professions that have been ruined by lexicalized phrases!
First: snake oil salesmen!

Since the phrase now means "con artist", nobody wants to be a snake oil salesman! But I presume there was a point when a man could procure some snake oil and go door-to-door selling it, and maybe those guys wrecked it for the rest of us. Maybe they were all chumps. MAYBE they were all, in fact, SUPERCHUMPS.
That may actually be the case!
I knew it!!

Yeah, early Western entrepreneurs tried to duplicate the successful Chinese snake oil they saw, but it failed to recognize the reason it had SOME effect was Chinese water snakes are high in eicosapentaenic acid, an anti inflammatory agent! Western snakes aren't, and so their medicine didn't work.
But they sold it anyway, often as a universal panacea!
PANACEA?! THAT'S THE SECRET WORD OF THE DAY!

transcription.title: i forgot to finish the list of professions ruined by lexicalized phrases yesterday! second was people who sell apple pies to anti-americans, on account of the phrase "as american as apple pie"? oh no, wait wait, i cut that out for a reason

panel.line: OH MY GOD. I just realized that yesterday when Utahraptor said "universal panacea", he was using a pleonasm!
(Pleonasm is the use of redundant, unnecessary words to express an idea!)

Hah hah! This is Utahraptor: "Hey, T-Rex, do you want to drink some cola-flavoured Coca-Cola brand carbonated cola beverages? Perhaps afterwards we'll take the public transport large road vehicle bus and buy with money or credit some submarine sub sandwiches?"
That's TOTALLY HIM, Domiceiomimus!
IT WAS A STYLISTIC CHOICE!
Sorry? Could your vocal chords and mouth repeat that?

Pleonasms have legitimate uses! For example, if I wasn't sure my audience (YOU, T-Rex) would know what "panacea" meant, I might use a similar word, allowing you to deduce some of my semantics without needing an explanation.
Maybe after the subs sandwiches we could go to a water lake beach shore?
We could go to the water lake beach shore in our water lake beach shore swimming shorts for swimming? In water?
You know what? FINE.
BUT IT'S WINTER!!

transcription.title: t-rex has travelled through time on many occasions. this is like a man on a plane suddenly having doubts about fixed-wing aircraft generating lift! IT WORKS BY REDIRECTING FLUID FLOW, AIRPLANE MAN

panel.line: Science dudes!
I have some bad news!
I think that time travel might not actually be possible!

Because say I travel to the future and take back some sweet future technology: let us say, hoverbikes. Nice! And then people in the present can examine the hoverbikes and see how they work to duplicate them, which is also nice, until we get to the future and the guy who invented hoverbikes won't do it anymore because they've already been invented! He doesn't want to be a copycat. Assume for the sake of argument that he doesn't want to be a copycat.
So, what? You've got a paradox!
Yes!
The creativity that was required to create hoverbikes has been erased! Who had the insight now?
It's a paradox! Those are what happen when you travel through time.
But they're inventions without an inventor and you can do the same thing with works of art!
Science dudes, are you even listening to me??

transcription.title: okay i have the leg cramp thing once in a while. i discovered a friend had the same issue, only her solution was to relax the muscle through massage! i thought it was pretty funny that my first instinct is to just slap the muscle around a bit

panel.line: Dear body! Here are some things you need to stop doing!
Aging?
Also, making weird noises.
Hah! What kind of noises?

Dromiceiomimus, yesterday I'm sitting there and my belly kind of goes "tweeeeet?" like it's a, a, a bird or something. What's with you, belly? I know you're there, yes! I don't need a "tweeeeet" to say hello. I just put food in you and that is gonna have to be INTRODUCTION ENOUGH.
Got any other body complaints?
As a matter of fact, I DO.

One, my body needs to survive in space, two, it needs to be able to eat paper in an emergency, three, flight would be nice, also, four, sometimes when I'm sleeping I get a cramp in my leg muscles and I have to punch the muscles.
Four is the worst?
Four is the worst! Also, FIVE, I wish my body would poop more instead of putting on weight.
Utahraptor (off-screen): Okay! I'm done with this conversation.
No, seriously! Because -
because i don't like being fat and pooping is good times

transcription.title: The alternate, sadder ending has a different last panel, where it's a few weeks earlier, and a woman is saying "T-Rex, that certainly took a long time and I didn't enjoy it at all", and T-Rex is thinking "but - she promised she'd be nice afterwards"

panel.line: SITUATIONS IN WHICH TO USE "THAT'S WHAT SHE SAID!"
There are many situations in which "that's what she said!" may be appropriately used! For example, after someone says, uh,
"What a good date!"

That's TERRIBLE. T-Rex, you're supposed to use it to recontextualize an innocuous statement into a double entendre, not to indicate that both people on the date were happy. Here, say it after I stop talking. "You can stay in my guest house for a week."
That's what SHE said!
See? Actually, no, that's not so great either.
Well, you can use "that's what she said!" when telling a story, too!
Literally?
Yeah, like - "Anneke said 'How do you do.' To clarify, that's what SHE said!"
Ug. Here, look: "T-Rex, that certainly took a long time and I didn't enjoy it at all."
That's what SHE said!
Hah!
Finally! Normally this isn't so hard!
That's what S-
Utahraptor, don't interrupt! I WAS SAYING, normally it doesn't take me THIS long to finish with something good, even if it's just a little ejaculation.

panel.line: CLIMATE CHANGE COMICS
CLIMATE CHANGE, huh?
There certainly is a lot of climate that's CHANGING, right? Right?! Can I get a witness?
Or MAYBE, climate isn't changing at all. Or maybe it is, but who cares because it's all someone else's fault!
or maybe the climate is supposed to change because we all got new swimmin' trunks
That is without exaggeration, T-Rex, the weakest comment on climate change that I have ever heard, or am ever likely to hear!
You've distilled an important issue down to "something might be happening I dunno, maybe??" Also, you don't even mention human influence on the climate, which is a serious concern!
Serious concern? I just stepped on a tiny woman, so her only influence on the climate is that now she's dead.
In the climate.
Right now she's probably saying "OH MAN WHAT A CHANGE FOR ME! A CLIMATE CHANGE, THAT IS!!"
Hey, remember when there were frogs?

panel.line: I love punch! I love drinking delicious punch, PROBABLY because of how it's so delicious.

QUITE LIKELY! I don't know why I'm suddenly so into what is essentially juice mixed with maybe pop or alcohol, served in a fancy bowl with spoons, but I'm running with it.
Well I guess I'll see you there tonight, punch in hand.
Oh God yes.
AT THE PARTY

"Snowbody loves me!"

transcription.title: i am trying to ascertain your baby's deal. a moment alone, please.

panel.line: A lot of my friends are having babies.
Book Cover: BABIES: "WHAT'S THE DEAL?"
Book Cover: a book by t-rex

That's what I say to them! They say, T-Rex, Marcia and I are expecting a little bundle of joy. And I say, Ted, I respect you and love you as a friend, but I have to ask - what's the deal? What is the deal with the BABIES.
The deal is that they're building a family and propagating the species!
That's just part of the deal!

As a man who is "without babies", the idea of being in charge of another person's life seems insane. That's a lot of responsibility, and I have no idea if I'm qualified for that - or if anyone ELSE is, for that matter. So I have to ask -
"What's the deal?"
With the babies, yes.
Book Cover: "OKAY, THANKS FOR WRITING IN TO TELL ME WHAT ALL THE DEALS WERE WITH YOUR BABIES"
Book Cover: "IT WAS A RHETORICAL QUESTION"

transcription.title: stories "4" men

panel.line: STORIES FOR MEN
Men! We like stories, right?
Three voices outside the picture: Right!
But they have to be good stories. Stories with plots in which there are good guys and bad guys, and then some explosions happen to them!
You sure like explosions, huh?

In a good story, they function as punctuation marks. Hamlet says "To be or not to be", and the building behind him blows up. It is spectacular. The audience whispers, "Yes. This is what Shakespeare meant."
So your story is Hamlet only with explosions instead of punctuation.
You say it like it's not fantastic!
Do the characters even react to the explosions at all?

Sometimes they go off in the background and they barely glance over their shoulder at them. Sometimes they outrun them down halls or by climbing up ladders real fast. It depends on the scene, you know?
THE ULTIMATE STORY FOR MEN

Hamlet sips some whiskey while punching a man in the nose! Ophelia says she's crazy for him and they go on a helicopter ride. A ghost appears, and when Hamlet high fives him he explodes! Then Denmark explodes.
Later, Ophelia's topless!

transcription.title: list of friends

panel.line: I have compiled a list of people I enjoy seeing! A list, if you will...
... of my friends!
Dromiceiomimus, you are on my list of friends!
Um - thanks?
Think nothing of it!
Tiny woman, you are NOT on my list! Prepare for a stomping!
What are you doing?!
Well, Utahraptor, I'm glad you asked. I've compiled a list of my friends and I am stomping on those who are not on my list!
Wow, you must have a lot of stomping to do.
Why yes, as a matter of fact I -
HEY! You're off the list!

transcription.title: stories "fore" women

panel.line: My stories for men were a huge success - but I've excluded half of my potential market!
STORIES FOR WOMEN

I've got a great idea, Dromiceiomimus: stories for women! Stories with FEELINGS. Stories where someone sighs deeply while looking at a photograph of someone else! In the photograph that someone else is ALSO sighing deeply.
That's what you think women want? Seriously?
Ha ha, of course not! This was just a hilarious test. Um.
Okay, so let's hear your real "stories for women" then!
Sure!
NO PROBLEM.
Two attractive people meet and fall in love. Then they take baths and hug.
Hah hah hah! "Take baths and hug"?
IT'S WHAT WOMEN WANT
THAT EVENING, TAKING A SHOWER:
Man, if this were a bath, and there was a woman here, and I was hugging her?
I'd be totally set!

transcription.title: stories "for" kids

panel.line: STORIES FOR KIDS
This one's easy!
that's because kids are EASILY ENTERTAINED. They just want bright colors that flash and spin! I can take care of that with a kaleidoscope. A story about a kaleidoscope, I mean.
So you're aiming for the under-six market?
No, no! I want twelve year olds too. So ah, the kaleidoscope can transform into a ninja turtle, who can mutate into a robot. Or a barbie. or a horse.
Or horse-Barbie. Done!
And so this is your ultimate story for kids?
Yes!
If by "story" you mean "franchise", anyway. I don't know. I think i've lost focus.
Why not focus on either babies OR children? That way you don't have to cater to both the "words are hard" and the "these early stages of puberty unsettle us all" demographics.
EARLIER:
Excuse me, child! Your early stages of puberty: they...they -
Child (off screen): They unsettle us all, I know.
Child (off screen): *sigh*
