transcription.title: A Modest Proposal: For Preventing Vandals the World Over from Being a Hilarious Burden to Wikipedia and Its Readers, and for Making Them Move Beneficial to the Stern, Encyclopaedia-Reading, Publick

panel.line: The Problem with Wikipedia is that it's peppered with vandalism at various times and at various locations: vandalism that remains until it's noticed by someone who knows enough and cares enough to fix it! SOMETIMES THIS CAN TAKE A WHILE. BUT!
*ahem*
Ladies and gentlemen: I have solved the Wikipedia Problem!

The solution is as brilliant as it is awesome: instead of vandalizing the ENTIRE encyclopedia, we all just agree to vandalize one article, leaving the other ones alone! That article is the one about chickens. Why? It's pretty obvious. DUDES ALREADY KNOW ABOUT CHICKENS.
In conceding that one TINY article to the vandals, Wikipedia wins! Their victory: a FULLY ACCURATE encyclopedia that covers every topic in the universe, 'cept chickens.
T-Rex, this is worse than taking on the mob! Wikipedia will be HELLUVA mad at you!
No way! I am doing them a FAVOUR.
Their vandalism problem GOES AWAY, FOREVER, and all that I ask is that chickens become The Forbidden Topic. "We never talk about chickens", they can say. "DON'T ASK."
But how are you going to get people to respect this idea? Plus, IS IT NOT TRUE THAT MANY WIKIPEDIA EDITORS ARE TRULY HUMOURLESS ABOUT WIKIPEDIA??
I guess we're about to find out! I bet Fictitional Jimbo Wales loves the idea.
Fictional Jimbo Wales: I do love this idea, T-Rex!
Fictional Jimbo Wales! You brought cupcakes!!

Um, sure! It's long, I guess, with lots of twists and turns, and some parts are dark so it's scarier, and everyone's screaming! Oh, and at the end, we all accidentally get chlorinated water in our eyes.

UTAHRAPTOR! What are you doing here?

I WAS WALKING BY AND COULDN'T HELP OVERHEARING. You're all "here's an example of an awkward pause!" but then set her up to say exactly what you want! Also it didn't even work, because nobody wants chlorinated water in their eyes on a date.

panel.line: Something people like to argue about sometimes is whether or not certain things are genetically innate, or personal decisions!

in comic form, baby

Is the whole nature/nurture debate really about assigning blame?
I think so! It doesn't change the "nature" (oh ho ho!) of what's being discussed, just its origin.
Well, it's not just about blame or credit, T-Rex, it's also about free will!
Free will?

Yeah, because if something important about you is fully determined by your genes, then you never had any control over that, and you're not responsible. You didn't have a choice. panel.line: Literally hours of work have paid off, and I have come up with my greatest invention yet...a DUPLICATOR RAY!

Yep! The duplicate is identical in every regard. The ray examines the object at the quantum AND subquantum levels and thanks to the twin fists of Actual Science and Heisenberg Compensators, makes a perfect copy, indistinguishable from the original!
I call baloney, T-Rex!

That's a property that doesn't have a physical realization, so you can't ever duplicate it!

Okay YEAH it's not original, but it's an OTHERWISE PERFECT DUPLICATE. I can destroy economies based on scarcity and generate clean drinking water for everyone! I can even DUPLICATE DUDES! I can't believe you're not more excited. I CAN DUPLICATE BRENT SPINER

transcription.title: it's called a negative income tax because instead of bottoming out at you owing the government $0, it can become negative, so the government can owe you money. that's right! taxes, bitches!

panel.line: A negative income tax, or "NIT", is when the government pays you money when your income is low! Pretty sweet!
NEGATIVE INCOME TAX COMICS
it will be interesting I PROMISE

But there is a catch. You still pay taxes - say, a flat tax of 10% - BUT, the government also pays you enough to survive! This way there's a guaranteed minimum income - like welfare, but simpler. So if you make only $1000 in a year you'll pay $100 in taxes, but since the government pays everyone, say, $10000, you'll end up $9900 ahead in tax money. As you make more money, you net less from the government, until you end up actually paying taxes!
So this acts to replace welfare?
Yep! And a bunch of related programs.
It simplifies things, plus it includes a flat tax, which a lot of amateur economists AS WELL AS even some real economists like!
I can see fraud being a problem, though, especially since if the fraud's successful, the government loses real money.
LATER:
Utahraptor! I just found out that Milton Friedman, proposer of the NIT, died yesterday at age 94!
One wonders if our conversation today would be an appropriate epitaph.
Dude! I believe this not to be the case!!

panel.line: I Have come up with a hilarious THREE-LEVEL PUN, Dromiceiomimus! Check it out! Instead of saying "I'll play it by ear", I point to my ear and say "I guess I'll play it by HERE!"

- but that is just level one of pun! I'm also pointing to my ear and saying "here", so there's level two (a visual pun!) and level THREE is how "here" sounds like "hear" and you can use ears to hear things. I'll play it by "hear", i.e., by how I hear it! It is a PERFECT STORM of wordplay, Dromiceiomimus! They make movies out of perfect storms.

transcription.title: i would make informed opinions about archaeology comics, but my only archaeologist friend is in grenada!

panel.line: [[UNINFORMED OPINIONS ABOUT ARCHAEOLOGY COMICS]]
I am a dude with some SERIOUSLY UNINFORMED opinions about archaeology!

Okay! We're digging up stuff all the time, right? And talk to any archaeologist and they'll complain about sites that have been damaged or destroyed by under-informed Victorian archaeologists that didn't have the knowledge and skills we have today. Doesn't it stand to reason that in 100 years we'll be making the same complaints about today's work? We only have so much history. Shouldn't we wait until we've perfected archaeology before we dig?
Well, doctors don't wait until medical technology is at a peak before operating!
True!
But dudes and ladies have finite lifetimes. The past isn't going anywhere! We can dig it up whenevs.
Perhaps it's only through excavation that archaeologists learn how to better their trade.
Perhaps!
Or perhaps it's hard to admit that hypothetical future people would be more on the ball than you could ever be!
Man, that's not hard! I suck at flying but fully expect future T-Rexes to be flying all over the place.
Thanks to the heady power of evolution?

transcription.title: t-rex's last line is supposed to be like a "damn it, ryan!" as you might say if i ruined your quiche AGAIN, and not a "damn it, the fuzz!" as you might say if the fuzz is hot on the trail of your latest caper. it kind of works both ways though

panel.line: INFORMED OPINIONS ABOUT ARCHAEOLOGY COMICS
Yes! I have actually done some research this time. Schwing!
And it turns out I was TOTALLY CORRECT!

Archaeologists ARE aware that they're mining a finite resource, and when possible, they only dig a little and leave some for the future. But there are time limits: often they'll be examining a site just before it's dug up for a new building of something, which means this is their last chance to see what's there before it's destroyed. And sometimes the ground is volatile enough that if they don't dig soon, whatever's there will be lost anyway!
In conclusion and in summary, way to go archaeologists!
Hooray for archaeologists!

T-Rex and Utahraptor: We have nothing but good things to say about the women and men of archaeology! Nothing but smiles for the trained and capable few who dedicate themselves towards exploring and explaining our shared history!
LATER: ARCHAEOLOGISTS TOTAL T-REX'S CAR!
Damn it, archaeologists!

transcription.title: we have a history: a web card

panel.line: WE HAVE A HISTORY
a web card
Dear recipient of this comic:
You and whoever went this card to you totally have a history together!
That's pretty intriguing, isn't it? What sort of history? Did you used to date? There's a lot I don't know about your history.
Maybe it's one sided! Maybe you don't even know who the sender is! Maybe he's this guy and HE thinks you have this history and YOU don't know him from Bob!
Maybe we should be more sensitive here, T-Rex!
YES. Good idea!

Besides, maybe the sender understands that you've both hurt each other in the past, but you're still friends, and he's glad for what happened, bad stuff and all. He knows you well and he's happy for that, and he cares for you in a way that's special and unique to you, history and all.
Aww!
Anyway! Enjoy your failed relationship(s)!

transcription.title: implausible high school AND college year AND new class scenarios

panel.line: Someone going by the all-caps name "ZACH MORRIS" has tagged my house! My front door is now spraypainted with "Zach" 's stupid name for jerks. I don't even like Saved by the Bell that much!
Forget you, Zach Morris!
I thought you always liked street art, T-Rex! You're always all, "Hey guys, let's reclaim public spaces with art instead of ads!"

Yeah, but this isn't art! It's tagging. It's just some dude's made up name! Taggers are like dogs, marking their territory wherever they can, and "Zach Morris" is just a dog who likes implausible high school scenarios. Either that, I guess, or Mark-Paul Gosselaar is bored. And experimenting?
I think you're ignoring the symbolism AND sociology behind tagging, T-Rex!
Explain!

Okay, so you grow up in the city, and the skyline is dominated by billboards, ads for products and brand you don't have access to. And you realize that nobody cares you you are, but EVERYONE knows who Mickey Mouse is and what a Coke is. So you create a brand name for yourself! You make up a tag and put it everywhere.

Tagging can really be seen as the next logical step in ads: self-advertising! It can be seen as the price we pay for a culture that has saturated itself with advertising: individual brands, internalized campaigns of self-promotion.
UTAHRAPTOR YOU ARE ZACH MORRIS

transcription.title: resolve to call more angry men 'sweetcakes'

panel.line: A new year is coming up. That means it is time to take stock of my life and make resolutions for improvements in the year to come!
THERE IS NO CHOICE IN THIS MATTER
RESOLUTION ONE:
eat less chickens!

I mean, eat FEWER chickens. "Fewer" is when you can count them, and "less" is when it's more of a mass and less countable, right? Like, I'd eat less rice, but I'd eat fewer COUNTABLY-MANY grains of rice.
I think you should resolve to be less obsessed about grammar!
Oh, Dromiceiomimus. Denied!!
So let's hear these other resolutions!
Of course! AFTER we talk about "less" and "fewer".

Isn't it neat that we have this distinction in English between fewer and elss, but the opposite, "more", covers both those cases? Our language is ASYMMETRICAL. If you want to encode countability in your "greater than" comparison word, then good luck! Hah! GOOD LUCK WITH THAT, MY FRIEND!
Okay!
LATER:
I ALSO resolve to get more smooches from ladies.

transcription.title: tony

panel.line: Guess who got a role in the new play down at the community centre?
Me!
I play Tony, a widower who has managed, alone, to raise his young daughter right. He's a rugged mechanic with a heart of gold, just waiting for the right person to come along...
...someone to melt his icy exterior and reveal the big furry Tony teddy-bear within!
Who's Tony?
Tony's a character I'm playing in a show.
Oh! For a second I thought you were describing me!
Both: Hah hah hah!
Not likely!

transcription.title: imagine living in a world where it was more common! i would rate this world: incredibly sad and incredibly surreal

panel.line: DISEASE COMICS
today's disease:
Fibrodysplasia Ossificans Progressiva, or "FOP"
FOP is one of the rarest conditions known to medicine!

It's a genetic disorder that causes muscles and connective tissue to literally change to bone. As more and more tissue becomes bone, joints become fused and the inflicted person is eventually left ossified and completely unable to move! Attempts to remove the extra bone simply result in further bone growth. It is a very painful disease and there is no cure, BUT, the gene that causes it has recently been found, which gives us hope!
Should we be talking about it like this? Isn't that a little - crass?
Not really!
We're spreading AWARENESS of the condition, which is a good thing!
Yeah, but it's such a sensational disease! Maybe we should - I don't know, try to be less sensational about it. We shouldn't be making jokes.
Who's making jokes? I'm not making jokes.
THE PRECEDING COMIC SHOULD NOT HAVE BEEN READ BY PEOPLE WHO ARE TERRIFIED OF GETTING EXTREMELY RARE GENETIC DISEASES

today's disease:
SMOOCHITIS
Smoochitis is when you have a MEDICAL case of the smooches!

We should smooch to make extra sure!

Man, I can't believe that worked!
She had smoochitis!!
The only cure: FURTHER SMOOCHING. Symptoms include smooches and caressing about the neck. And buttocks?
I know how smoochitis develops, yeah.
It's my SPECIALTY, baby!

transcription.title: t-rex wants a mortgage and a nice pair of pants.

panel.line: I am getting old! WHICH IS FINE, except I'm starting to worry that all I do is young guy stuff and not mature adult stuff, like having a mortgage, or owning more than one pair of nice pants.
T-REX COMICS

I'm a little surprised by my own feelings! I've always been a guy to be fully behind doing what you want and SCREW SOCIETY, but I there's a part of me whispering "come on get a real job and a mortgage and live a real life it'll be raaaad". Maybe it's societal conditioning, but it's there! I guess I either need to change my life OR my opinions, or accept that little bit of discomfort for as long as I live.
Discomfort?
Yes! With my LIFE.
Hah! You're finally not sure your days of INSATIABLY COMPELLING HEDONISM are all you want?
Maybe! I guess I look at people with real responsibility and wonder if maybe it'd be nice, and if I'm being - left behind? I don't know? I never wanted to be Canonically Adult before!
WHATEVER, T-REX! HERE'S ANOTHER TIME YOU WANTED TO BE CANONICALLY ADULT:
YOU DIDN'T SAY ANYTHING BUT WE COULD ALL TELL YOU WERE THINKING IT.

transcription.title: mister alex ross if you want to please draw this i will script it

panel.line: So, Dromiceiomimus: Do you know how to draw superheroes? I've got such a great idea for a comic.
(IN THIS PANEL, DROMICEIOMIMUS SAYS YES)

Sweet! Okay, so the idea is, there's this guy, Lee, right? One day he gains SUPER POWERS. And I'm not sure how he gets them yet but BASICALLY he's got this slot in the top of his head, and he can write words on cards and put them in the slot, so he gains those qualities! So say a decision has to be made: he writes "decisive" on a card and forces it into his head, and he becomes DECISIVE LEE! He then has the power to do things decisively, SUPER decisively!
So he's got any power that can be described by an English adverb ending in "ly"?
PRECISELY!

But not just Precise Lee, he can be Compelling Lee, Obliging Lee - even Furious Lee! But the catch is, the cards stick out, so enemies know what they're dealing with. "Oh cool, we're dealing with Conclusive Lee", they'll say. "We can ask him some questions."
I see
FIFTY YEARS LATER
Have I TRULY won every single award in comics?

transcription.title: the best deleted dialogue for this comic was 'you make my atheism difficult, god'. the worst was 'colonel bluegrass, i want my pliers back'

panel.line: I'm a dude who's really not that religious! I'm not a big believer in DEITIES.
WHAT
But I don't like it when someone says they've lost their faith because of me!

Because faith is something I don't really have, it's sort of like a sandcastle, right? And I don't want to be the guy that goes around kicking other people's sandcastles. Even if they thank me afterwards! Faith is something rare, at least for me, and I'd hate to take it away from someone else.
That's pretty patronizing, isn't it?
Not really!
Sure! You're saying "I won't tell you about MY amazing beliefs because they would completely obliterate yours! Also: your religion is made of sand."
Thant's not what I'm saying! WHO'D HAVE THOUGHT this frank talk about religion would result in heated debate?
JUST THEN, ALL RELIGIOUS DEBATES EVER ARE SETTLED FOREVER! NICE!
Well! I guess that gives us more time to talk about - I don't know. Dogs? I guess we could talk about dogs.
Out-of-Frame Voice, Likely Utahraptor: I like dogs!

transcription.title: if there's ever a zombie epidemic, i pledge to be the first - the first! - to blame the sucky zombies.

panel.line: Today is the day. Yes!
Today is the day I lose my fear of ZOMBIES.
T-REX AND THE LIVING DEAD

The way I see it, zombies are either avoidable or too effective. The only way to become a zombie is to be bitten by one, but not to get eaten, yes? Then the bite kills you and you come back as a zombie. But zombies WANT to eat you! It's only the sucky ones that bite you and don't finish the job. So if the first zombie was REALLY GOOD, the infection wouldn't spread, because he'd cold eat all his victims! And if he was sucky you could just avoid him, on account of his suckiness.
PROBLEM: SOLVED.
You're coming from a medical perspective, right?
The idea is that there's not too many diseases that can spread easily AND kill you overnight, because they're too effective: the infection wouldn't spread, and the disease dies.
Yes! Zombies are too effective to be contagious. That's why they can't exist in real life!
LATER: FAST-MOVING PULMONARY ANTHRAX ZOMBIES
I take it back I take it back!!

transcription.title: another comic in which t-rex's tail gets a line

panel.line: I have discovered the ultimate secret to comedy! The more obscure a joke is, the less people there are who'll get it, but the MORE they'll find it correspondingly HILARIOUS! I suspect this law progresses geometrically.
For example!

Let's say I have a joke about how cats like to sleep. NOT FUNNY, right Dromiceiomimus? Everyone who's met a sleepy ol' cat can get that. But if I have a joke about how, say, an obscure programming language is pretty wacky, then people who know that language will feel like I'm talking to them! They laugh both at the joke AND in recognition. Comedy increases, and the only reasonable conclusion is "laughs ahoy!"
So logically, ALL I HAVE TO DO is find a really rich guy and tell him a joke only HE'D find funny, and I'm set for life!
Huh?
Dude, rich people LOVE to give people money when they make them laugh! And I'm going to track down Patrick Stewart and make him laugh SO HARD. You don't even know.
Patrick Stewart? Is he really that loaded that he gives money away for funny jokes?
Um, HE COMMANDED THE ENTERPRISE?
[[The cover of the latest 'The Patrick Stewart Press'.]]
The Patrick Stewart Press: The Patrick Stewart press
january 2007 - 25 cents - *all my views and news!*
[[Featuring a picture of T-Rex]]
this guy's hilarious!
who is this guy?
plus: i review the new MACBOOKS

transcription.title: my one regret as a computer scientist is that we never have a reasonable excuse to wear lab coats. what gives, society?

panel.line: So light behaves like both a particle and a wave, right? And I can hit dudes with particles. Is there nothing stopping me from making a light cannon, which, when fired, throws dudes up against the wall?
Weaponized photons!

But T-Rex - photons don't have any mass, do they? If they had mass, wouldn't that mean that walking outside on a sunny day would mean being hit with trillions of tiny bullets, reducing everything to a red, pulpy, well-lit paste?
But then how do solar sails work? And photon engines? Don't they work by photons pushing against things? HAS SCIENCE FICTION BEEN LYING THROUGH ITS SCIENCE TEETH?
Maybe even without mass, photons can still exert pressure!
Perhaps!!
And if solar sails work, THEN SO TOO WILL MY LIGHT CANNON! I'll just need tons of light
I think you'd need more than the entire output of the sun!
THAT, my friend, would be a pretty sweet cannon slash flash-light. Quick! To Professor Science's house!
Soon:
I don't think he's home.
Sure he is. PROFESSOR SCIENCE! IT'S T-REX, UTAHRAPTOR, AND DROMICEIOMIMUS! We brought LABCOATS!

transcription.title: everyone throwing their hands up in the air at work - don't worry! i won't get you fired. YOU CAN'T GET FIRED FOR BEING AWESOME!

panel.line: Have I TRULY never thrown my hands up in the air, and waved them all around like I just don't care?
{{T-Rex heaves his arms into the area immediately above their current locale, proceeds to move them in an arc, back and forth, as if he has other things on his mind.}}
I don't see what the big deal about it is! I BARELY feel funkier.
I feel a little funkier.
I guess I feel a little funkier. A LITTLE.
Man, you weren't even doing it right!!
Oh yeah? Says you, Utahraptor!
Says me, T-Rex! Okay, listen, THIS is how you throw your hands up in the air. And watch closely, because I'm only going to wave them all around like I just don't care ONCE.
I'm watching!
Okay. Here we go!

panel.line: HILARIOUS MISUNDERSTANDINGS COMICS
Oh oh...

Did you just say that my SON is hot today?

Jesus!

Hi!

transcription.title: if you come at four o'clock in the afternoon, then by three o'clock i shall begin to be happy

panel.line: I want to write something that'll make people see the world through fresh eyes! Something they'll want to pass on to their children!
YOU WANT TO WRITE THE LITTLE PRINCE
BASICALLY.
Except that's been done! I want something NEW that will touch the heart of everyone, WITHOUT EXCEPTION.
This is the desire authors have, isn't it? To say something new that is nevertheless eternal? To really touch people, to change their lives for the better using only their ideas?
I guess! I bet some authors just want to tell jokes about dinosaurs though.
T-Rex and Dromiceiomimus: That wouldn't be so bad
So -- get to work! Get to writing!
I can't! I need INSPIRATION.

Okay, here: take something that's common to everyone, and present it in an empathic, sympathetic light. How about -- letting down someone you love! We've all done it and I don't think anyone enjoys it. There's pathos there.
Brilliant! You've really helped me out, Utahraptor!
SOON:

I call my tale, "The Alluring Person with Hidden Greatness (Just Like You!) Who Accidentally Let Down Someone he Loves but then Made Amends and They Kissed: An Action-Packed Tale of the Star Wars Universe, But Afterwards They Visit The Enterprise and Bender Is There"

transcription.title: see what i did there

panel.line: It's neat how most of our key verbs are just one syllable long! I think that verbs we use a lot change to short words with time, since if they did NOT, it would take a real long time to say all the run-of-the-mill thoughts we have!
We'd get bored each time we'd try to talk!
Sex! Love! Hate! BONE. All are rad AND short verbs! I bet you could use just short WORDS and find it to be not that hard of a trick!
You might end up with an odd phrase or two, though, since you'd have to steer clear of all 'ing' verbs.
Well, that verb form is for chumps! I said it! That verb form is for true chumps.
Do you have some sort of proof for this "short means key" view?
In fact I do!

There's a set store of short words, right? A hoard, if you will. If we used all the short word forms for weird and rare verbs, like, I don't know, "to eat a lot of pork", then it would take a long time to share a thought that did not come down to "Dudes! I want to eat pigs!"
Come on! That's not a proof!
I have one word for you, my friend!
Yes?
Daaaaaaaaaamn

transcription.title: deleted dialogue had utahraptor saying ''There's a 'politicians sure do say one thing and mean another' joke in here somewhere.'' and T-Rex replying ''Not a funny one.''

panel.line: Why can't I say two things at the same time? I've tried just now and all I got out of it was a passport stamped for FAILURE TOWNE.
FAILURE TOWNE IS ITS OWN INDEPENDENT NATION HUH
Apparently, dude!

But saying a word is just generating a sound wave, right? I could record myself twice saying different things, and then superimpose their waves to get a new one! Then all I'd need to do is train myself to produce THAT wave and it would sound like I'm saying two things at once! I could even do it by rote. Then when people ask me to do things I could say "yes" and "no" at the same time, and then they'd probably dislike me a little.
I think we've got physical limitations to prevent this!
Balderdash!

You're just saying that because you've never seen it done, dear friend! But I'm gonna do it. I'm gonna figure out how to shape my tongue and mouth and vocal cords to generate the appropriate waveform, and then I'm gonna TRAVEL THE WORLD, saying two things at once.
Okay!

BOTTLED INSPIRATION COMICS
So - it's a perfume called "Inspiration" and you drink it, for some reason?

No. No, it's nothing like that. It's actual bottled inspiration! I came up with it when I chemically and accidentally created just a little inspiration, and when I drank that, I was inspired to create more! There's a whole pool full of it back at my house. You can drown in it.

SECRETS! And chemicals. A mix of both, I guess.

transcription.title: we don't eat people, we are people. additionally, we eat people.

panel.line: Critical mass rides are when a hundred or more cyclists get together and go on a bike ride! They take over a lane of traffic and get to set their pace. The motto and politics are "we don't block traffic, we are traffic!"
It's good times, if you're not in a car!
I find it encouraging when I see a bunch of bikes taking over a road and just going on their way. The noise of traffic is replaced by the softer sound of spokes and gears. It's pretty neat!
But what about important vehicles, like ambulances and so on?
Oh, they still pull over to let those through. They just don't let cars merge in with the bikes because it's DANGEROUS.
But T-Rex, is it not ENTIRELY TRUE that these rides are illegal?
Depends on who you ask, dude!
And where you live, I suppose. I don't know! I know I like to ride bikes, and I believe they're as entitled to the road as cars. The end!
Alright then!
Well!
You wanna get sandwiches?

transcription.title: do the dishes

panel.line: I really don't like doing the dishes.
That is why I will ask the Utahraptor to do them for me!

I'll be able to cook all sorts of fancy foods now that I'm freed of that soul-crushing chore of doing the damned dishes!
Hey! I heard you were looking for me?

: How would you like to do my dishes for me?
No thanks!
But -
You're sure?

transcription.title: nanite comics

panel.line: NANITE COMICS
Nanites are tiny robots! They're SO TINY that they can robotically mess with things at the molecular level.
Pretty darned sweet, my friends!

The dream is that you could pour a vial of nanites on your bed and they'd transform it at the "nano" level into a better bed, or a big ol' pile of tasty burgers! You could eliminate hunger, dispose of waste, and so on. The only downside is that the nanites could malfunction, reproduce without check, and reduce all life to a featureless grey goo.
Or to burgers.
OR to burgers.
I thought there were issues with the "grey goo" scenario being impossible?
Maybe?
I AM probably confusing science fiction nanites with real nanites. But one thing we can all agree on is that nanites are pretty neat.
Can we also all agree that if there was a superhero who could shrink really small, he should be called "The Manite"?
YES WE CAN.
MEANWHILE, IN THE FUTURE:
It's Nanite versus Manite! Two titans battling for dominance of my affections!
Nanite: i'm a tiny robot
Manite: i'm a tiny dude
GUYS, I KNOW.

transcription.title: in 1979 a chinese climber named wang hongbao claimed to have seen a body of an english climber, but was killed by an avalanche a day later before a translator could be found and he could communicate precisely where. HOW IS THAT NOT AMAZING

panel.line: George Mallory and Andrew Irvine were the two British dudes who first tried to climb Mount Everest!
THE STORY OF GEORGE MALLORY AND ANDREW IRVINE (INCREDIBLE TRUE PART)

Their last sighting was just a few hundred metres from the summit. They never made it back! A STANDARD MOUNTAINEERING TALE, except that if they had made it to the top, they'd have been the first, AND they were carrying cameras. If we could find the frozen cameras we could still retrieve images from them today, and then we'd know if they actually did make it to the top, since who climbs Mount Everest and doesn't take a picture? NOBODY, that's who.
Didn't other climbers find the bodies?
Only one!
Mallory's body was found 75 years later, but no cameras were on him. Irvine's body is still up there somewhere, maybe with the cameras!
Wow. There's something so spooky and sad about their bodies being frozen like that. It's like a treasure hunt with a perfectly preserved corpse at the end.
WILD SPECULATION PART:

Speculation Text: Could all "mountaineering accidents" be the handiwork of a lone, crazed murderer, loose about the peak? IT COULD BE TRUE!! If so, no-one has survived their encounter with the pushy "Everest Eliminator" and lived to tell the tale.
That's ridiculous!
Speculation Text: No. That's MURDER.

transcription.title: boing boing please to start posting about the everest eliminator now

panel.line: T-REX AND UTAHRAPTOR ARE GOING TO CLIMB MOUNT EVEREST:

And if I stay too long at the top of the stairs, I'll die!
Are you guys serious about this? I know that Everest has become touristy lately, but I didn't know they let just anyone climb it!

They sure do. We're going STRAIGHT TO THE TOP, baby! We'll see if the deadly Everest Eliminator exists or not. SOME claim he's a wacky murderer who pushes people off the peak when they're least expecting it! Others say that's stupid.
That's not why we're going!
We're going Because It's There. And also Because We Won Free Tickets From The Radio. Also because hired sherpas will do most of the work.
Well, I'M going because it's there AND to prove that there's no murderer called the Everest Eliminator at the top.
FINE.

He only tried to pus me a li'l!

transcription.title: ''sexy is distracting, ON THE MOON'': the typo that became dialogue

panel.line: I just realized that no women have ever been to the moon! ONLY DUDES. DUDES WHO RETURNED AS MEN.
Apparently, you need a sausage to get on the moon!
Wait - that's actually correct, isn't it? The moon totally IS an old boys' club!

Yep! I know we're being sensationalistic here, since there's only been thirteen people on the moon EVER, and that's a pretty small sample size. But still! No women! No grandmothers! NO SULLEN TEENS (FEMALE). Just men!
Also: no asians?
Is there a reason why all the Apollo missions were crewed by dudes?
Um, it was the 60s?
I guess! And I guess you could make an argument for "sexy is distracting, ON THE MOON." But sexy is distracting everywhere! You know?
I suppose this legacy of sexism will be with us until we, as a people, finally return to the moon with chicks.
SOON:

It may, sir!

a comic for people who are way into getting married
If you want to get married then first you need to find a mate! You need to find a LIFE PARTNER.

transcription.title: t-rex apparently believes all westerns are john ford westerns, but that's okay. i could live with that.

panel.line: I was going to write a science fiction story, but then I stopped. I realized I don't know what science fiction, as a genre, means!
Seriously! I had some DOUBTS.

If I was writing a western I could go on and on about order versus freedom, civilization versus the wilderness, the hero as a man stuck between these two worlds, and so on! But what's science fiction about? Is it just literature with space ships and robots and casually inverted flux variance? Aliens stopped being parallels for The Other long ago, didn't they?
Why are you worried about this, T-Rex? It's just a genre label!
So?
So - it's something that's applied to your work after it's completed. Unless you want to write specifically to a generic form, you don't have to worry about it!
My other problem is I don't have a plotline either.
Man! Why not write a story about a cat then. You like cats.
T-REX READS HIS STORY, CALLED "FUTURE T-REX AND THE CAT", TO MORRIS:
Once upon a time there was a cat. He was obese.
I saw him on the bus!
Morris: booooooo

panel.line: Poker sure seems to be popular lately! Does the road to financial independence TRULY pass through Gambling Towne, USA?
THE ANSWER IS NO
There's one way to find out!
YOU'RE NOT LISTENING T-REX I DON'T WANT TO SEE YOU RUINED DUE TO HILARIOUSLY SUCKY POKER PLAYING

Yeah but, you can lose at lotteries because it's just chance, right? But in poker, you can bluff! IN THEORY, I can bluff my way into the annals of poker history AND the annals of "neighbours with suspicious amounts of disposable income", ALL AT THE SAME TIME. All I need is a good poker face!
And, you know, skills at poker!
What? I've got mad skills at poker!
I believe, canonically, the minimum skill set is knowing when to hold them, as well as being aware of the proper time at which to fold them.
That is advice for people WITHOUT the ultimate poker face. Check this out.
poooooker
YES, THIS IS T-REX'S POKER FACE. HE MAKES EYE CONTACT, SMILES, AND WHISPERS "POOOOOKER"
I've doubled my money!
RIGHT ON

transcription.title: this comic was gonna have more mistakes in it, but then it was really depressing. HOW BOUT THOSE ERRORS WE MAKE IN OUR OWN LIVES HUH

panel.line: I guess I've been pretty lucky to get this far without making any big, life-altering mistakes. I think the biggest mistake I ever made was mixing up some juice from concentrate that had a ladybug in it!
MISTAKE COMICS
Eww! How did that ever happen!

I was experimenting with mixing juice with a blender, and I guess there was a ladybug in the blender? ALL I KNOW is that when the blender turned off and the smoke cleared, my hitherto delicious juice had clearly-identifiable ladybug pieces floating on top. I recall saying "Aw man! My JUICE!"
So - did you drink the juice!
No! Of course not!

But that's not what I wanted to talk about. I wanted to talk about how one bad decision can totally change your life, you know? Lost limbs, broken friendships, unexpected pregnancies with someone you don't really like: stuff like that.
I woulda thought you'd drink the juice.
I THINK WE'D ALL RATHER HEAR ABOUT THE BUG JUICE T-REX
FINE. It was the worst juice, everyone. IT had guts in it!
HAH HAH HAH
EWWWWWWWW

transcription.title: friends and neighbours, yes, i hypothesize a universe in which superman is real and dinosaurs didn't die out. IT MAY WELL BE THE GREATEST UNIVERSE EVER

panel.line: The essential problem with Superman, as a character, is that he's too powerful and incorruptible. He's a walking deus ex machina! You give him a foe he can't beat, and all he has to do is TRY HARDER, and then he beats the guy.
What I'm saying is that this is not truly satisfying!

The way to make Supes interesting is to put him up against a problem that he can't fix by punching someone through a building! Put him in a situation where, say, everyone he loves starts dying of a disease that he can't detect or cure, passing away in his arms, one by one. At the end he's left as the sole survivor of the doomed planet Earth, six billion dead - only this time, he had a chance to stop the disaster, and he FAILED.
That's a terrible story, T-Rex!
It's modern, AND dark!
Yeah, and it destroys the character! Superman is a symbol of hope, and you have him basically standing up and shouting "HOPE IS USELESS AGAINST A SUPERIOR FOE" and then everyone Earth dies.
I bet if Superman were real he'd like my story. He'd say to me, "That was a SUPER interesting story, T-Rex!"
MEANWHILE, IN THE UNIVERSE WHERE SUPERMAN IS REAL!
Superman! If I jump off this building will you save me?
Superman: Don't jump off that building!
Will you save me though?
I'm just gonna jump real quick, okay?

transcription.title: ATTENTION WOMEN NAMED SAMANTHA IN THE AUDIENCE: t-rex and i agree, you have pretty names.

panel.line: T-REX TODAY IS THE DAY FOR TOTAL EMOTIONAL HONESTY
Nopers!!
TODAY is the day of continuing to leave certain emotions unstated AND/OR ignored!

This is because total honesty has the power to DESTROY relationships! FOR EXAMPLE, Dromiceiomimus, if we're in a committed monogamous relationship, I don't want my friend or even a random dude coming up to you and saying how he loves you more than anything and how he could never admit it until now! I want him to suffer in silence. For the greater good!
Is he hot?
You're privileging your happiness over his!
No! I'm just looking at TOTAL happiness.
My girlfriend and I are in love, and my friend and I are happy. This equals 15 happiness points, 10 for love and 5 for friendship.
Okay.
But if he confesses love to her, I'm now UNhappy with my friend, and we're down 5 HP! Forget THAT noise.
I think you're just setting up this point system so that it supports you and your lady friend staying together!
UTAHRAPTOR STAY AWAY FROM MY GIRLFRIEND
WHEN I GET ONE
HER NAME WILL BE "SAMANTHA"; IT IS A PRETTY NAME

transcription.title: i like slam dancin' and slam romancin'

panel.line: Alright! Time for me to meet a nice woman named Samantha, as per my prediction of yesterday! I will romance her until she no longer desires further romancin'. The romancin' will be mutual.
ROMANCIN' COMICS

T-Rex, you're my friend and I respect you, but you're not really ROMANTIC. Romance requires emotional swagger and sensitivity, but you've inured yourself to all but the most amusing of feelings, you know? You just attract through other means.
What?! I can be romantic!!
Hold on a sec; I'll get you some chocolates and diamonds.
That's not really romance, T-Rex!
Chocolates plus diamonds equals romance, dude!
The GESTURE is what's romantic: the chocolate and diamonds are just the instantiation of the gesture. Without any meaning behind it, the chocolates are just tasty times!
Well, UTAHRAPTOR, you're going to have to take THAT up with TV, print and radio commercials, who disagree!
They're personified across the street. HEY, COMMERCIALS PERSONIFIED! Utahraptor wants to talk to you about romance!
Personified commercials: Hello there, consumer! Did you know that a diamond is FOREVER, just like the love between two people with finite lifespans?
'Kay! I 'll see you kids later!

transcription.title: what would the world be like if the roman empire had never fallen? let's watch this star trek episode to find out!

panel.line: ALTERNATE HISTORY COMICS
Oh goodness, do I love alternate histories. What would the world be like if Nazis won World War II?
I know! Let's watch a movie to find out!

I think what I like is the fun of going back and finding one event and just flipping it, then reasonably tracing the changes up to the present. It really can be an intellectual exercise! I also like how alternate histories imply that each of our daily actions could have TIMELINE-ALTERING CONSEQUENCES.
Well, not ALL of our actions, T-Rex! Just the big ones.
Perhaps...
But, Utahraptor... perhaps NOT!
O-Okay.
Now, if you'll excuse me, I'M going to change all our tomorrows. Farewell!
T-REX TELL ME WHAT YOU'RE PLANNING TO DO AND I'LL TELL YOU HOW IT AFFECTS THE FUTURE
I'm writing a story in which I eat a lot of sandwiches! Then I'm gonna ACTUALLY eat a lot of sandwiches.
OKAY

panel.line: I have a pretty good knowledge of my closest friends. I know their likes and dislikes and can predict how they'd react in most situations!
I have constructed nothing less than FRIEND SIMULATORS in my very mind!

It's pretty great, Dromiceiomimus! Sometimes I'll ask myself "What's Utahraptor probably doing this weekend?" or "What would Dromiceiomimus do if she found out I ate all these chicken legs?" and I use my friend simulators to asnwer these questions.
I guess that's true for me too! Also, I'd ask you if those chicken legs made you happy.
they didn't
So what's your Utahraptor simulator like?
Like you!
He fills in when you're not around or when it'd be ridiculous to ask you what you thought of something. He also tells me what you want for your birthday. What's your T-Rex simulator like?
He's um - he's okay!

booooooooooooooners

transcription.title: TR? L?V ?

panel.line: Maybe today is the day I meet the love of my life, but ONLY if I go to the supermarket, because that's where she is!
I should get some friggin' groceries!
BUT - maybe she's NOT at the grocery store. Maybe she's nearby, and by going to the grocery store, I'd miss her and we'd never meet! Maybe I'm sabotaging my future RIGHT NOW as I speak!
MAYBE YOU ARE, T-REX
The point is that if you've only got one "true love" in the world, then the odds of meeting her are super small.
I thought we decided "true love" could apply to more than one person!
Oh, we did!
But THEN I realized I can probably love one lady more than another. Rank them by happiness and you've got my best match, my "true love", right at the top!

panel.line: Okay! I am going to write a story and it will be something BRAND NEW. It will be the most staggeringly original story ever. It will feature action and characters that COULD NEVER HAVE BEEN CONCEIVED BY ANYONE BUT ME.

transcription.title: sorry, avogadro's number day. you don't get a comic.

panel.line: Today is Pi Day! That means you get to eat pie at 1:59 PM, or 1:59 AM if you're up. I don't know.
I feel a profound disconnect with this holiday!

I get that it's celebrating the UNIVERSAL CONSTANT PI, and that it's celebrated today because 3.14159 can be translated into Mach 14th, 1:59. But what makes pi so special? Why don't we celebrate Euler's Number day on... February 71st?
Some people celebrate "Pi Approximation Day" on July 22nd, which is 22/7.
Hah! Now THAT is a holiday I can get behind!
What? You're all down on Pi Day but you can get behind an approximation of it?
Sure can, dude!
It's a holiday for people who are GOOD ENOUGH, just not transcendental! They do their best! They get by alright in most situations - just don't try to build a bridge with them, you know?
It celebrates failure?
Not failure, Utahraptor! Approximations of success!
On July 22 instead of eating pie, I'm just going to sort of rub pie around my face and call it a day!
Good luck with that.
Failure is just success rounded down, my friend!

transcription.title: it's so exciting that everyone has leapt up off their seats!

panel.line: What I miss is scenes in movies where people would be yelling at each other, and then they'd both stop, stare at each other for a beat, and then they'd be making out! WHY DOES THAT NOT HAPPEN ANYMORE? It was awesome!
(It was seriously awesome!)

And time was it was a necessary feature of every great movie - just like car chases are today! You could go into a theatre and be GUARANTEED the slap across the face / smooch on the lips combo, SOMETIMES even before the opening credits were over. It was good times! I like the car chases, of course, but I miss the nuance of the old topos. Great actors would bring such subtlety to the face slap - such pathos to the ensuing makeouts!
I missed the "car chases are necessary in every great movie today" memo!
Necessary AND sufficient!
And like I said, they're fantastic, but they don't lend themselves to the smooches. Today's actors COULD yell at each other and then make out during a car chase, but they never do.
Never?
Well, I keep waiting.

Character 1: You're a bastard!

Characters: *smooch smooch smooch*
Character 1: Wait, I need to focus on the road!

panel.line: Anachronism is when you have technology being used before it was invented! It happens whenever Shakespeare listens to his MP3s.
LITERARY TECHNIQUE COMICS
today's technique: ANACHRONISM

Ah, anachronism! It can also happen by accident, like when an author forgets that people didn't write with ballpoint pens 100 years ago or that elves didn't have friggin' computers. Sometimes if it's a really obvious error it can be played for comedy.
It is an advanced literary technique used by only our most handsome authors!
So when someone has a time machine, is that anachronism?
Unfortunately, no!
Time machines are a special case. If there is a time machine in the story then a lot of anachronism can be explained by the time machine, and is thus NO LONGER ANACHRONISM.
I like that this is the one literary technique that has allowances for time travel.
Yeah. It's the best.
MEANWHILE, IN TUDOR ENGLAND!
Shakespeare! Are you listening to your MP3s again?!
Shakespeare: so what if i am

transcription.title: if the house or car were speaking in panel three, then one could reasonably argue that there was some anthropomorphism occuring in Dinosaur Comics

panel.line: Anthropomorphism is when you have things that normally can't talk walking around and behaving like people! It happens whenever a toaster flips you off.
LITERARY TECHNIQUE COMICS
today's technique: ANTHROPOMORPHISM

Anthropomorphism is often used in childrens' stories where you have talking animals, but can also be used in more adult works! This is because occasionally adults enjoy it when a cat is sassy. Sometimes, a character will be anthropomorphized by mistake, like when you write a play and accidentally attribute dialogue to a ceiling tile. The ceiling tile is said to be "anthropomorphized" if the oversight is not corrected in a timely fashion.
We all know what anthropomorphism is, dude!
Aw man, really?
Yep! We've actually talked about it before, remember? But - you know, thanks for the reminder!
Well, you're welcome! Anytime you need anthropomorphism explained, just drop me a line.
Gotcha.
Narrative: MEANWHILE, IN TUDOR ENGLAND!
Shakespeare, are you flipping off your toaster again? It's 3 AM!
Shakespeare: he started it!!

transcription.title: understanding ethical relativism

panel.line: I feel that I know what's best for me, and I have no right to judge your beliefs.
All beliefs and ethics are "relative"!
UNDERSTANDING ETHICAL RELATIVISM
I stomp this house because I feel it would be a good idea to do so! Do not judge me, Dromiceiomimus!
But I believe it is wrong! Which of us is right?
That is the beauty of relativism: we both are!
Ethical relativism is the best philosophy ever!
Oh really?!

It can be argued that in every rational person (the definition of 'rational' is a touchy subject I won't discuss here) there are certain properties common to all. The problem (well, one problem) with relativism is how it nihilistically privileges the experience of the individual above all else, making every ethical decision the right ethical decision: who would not like to have his or her beliefs guaranteed to be as correct as anybody else's? But this is done at the cost of ignoring our shared qualities, turning away from the fact that despite different languages and cultures (and continents and skin colours) we all believe some of the same things. With that striking fundamental truth removed, the baby-rapers and the saints stand side by side, equals in righteousness.

But your first assumption is flawed! I doubt you can find even one universal constant; even your revealing example of baby-rape is practiced by some! Granted, these people are considered" monsters", but isn't that just a case of the majority condemning a minority? I don't mean to justify baby-rape, but only to point out that it's unlikely you can come up with even one belief that is universal!

panel.line: Allusion is a reference to a person, place, or thing in a piece of literature! Like when Picard mentions Moby Dick in Star Trek: First Contact?
LITERARY TECHNIQUE COMICS
today's technique:
ALLUSION

Allusions are pretty handy because they allow you to summarize potentially complex ideas with one succinct reference, essentially piggybacking on the brilliance of previously established works! HOWEVER, if the audience isn't familiar with the reference, the alluson fails and can seem weird or out-of-place.
Just like Oliver Brackenbury!!

panel.line: In CONCLUSION, anachronism, anthropomorphism and allusion are the only three literary techniques! There aren't any others. Okay there were some others but they died.
LITERARY TECHNIQUE COMICS
today's technique:
ALL THE REST
But what about foreshadowing? Denouement? SYNECDOCHE?

All dead! Today's readers yawn in the face of foreshadowing! They wince when seeing ANY events that occur after the climax! They throw up a little when a part is used to represent the whole! You can tell when that's happened because you'll go to the library and hear "Synedoche?! bleggh"

THE REVENGE OF T-REX

transcription.title: as soon as you buy into solipsism you change "I think, therefore I am" into "I think, therefore maybe some guy made me up?" and that is LESS CATCHY.

panel.line: The opposite of solipsism (where you believe you are the only real person who is imagining a universe) is antisolipsism, in which you believe everyone is real except you! I may have just made this up. Anyway!
You believe you're totally fake!
You're just a sustained figment of everyone else's imagination. The only issue with THAT is how everyone is imagining the same dude at the same time so well.
Perhaps they're imagining different things, but whenever anyone imagines you, they also imagine you up a whole universe, history, and consistent sense of self!
Perhaps!
Or perhaps it's just one person doing the imagining!
Yes!

If you buy into solipsism, then what are the odds you're the chosen one? Maybe there's some actual solipsist who really IS the only real thing going, and they're imagining everything for you, even when you're not around. What a card, huh? What a crazy dude!
That's what I'm saying!
If you believe one person can imagine a universe, you have to believe they can imagine your thoughts too, and then you've got no reason to believe you're real!
Let's go tell a solipsist, and then punch him, and then say "Stop imagining punching yourself!"
Then: ice cream!

transcription.title: like kurosawa i make mad films, 'kay i don't make films, but if i did they'd have a zombie guy

panel.line: Similar to antisolipsism but ACTUALLY REAL is the Cotard Delusion, in which the person affected believes they have died.
So it goes!

The condition was first identified over 100 years ago. This is UNFORTUNATE, because it was identified before the proper nomenclature was in place. It should've been called :I Think I Might Be A Zombieitis."
That's a little disrespectful, plus, that don't hunger for living flesh.
'I Think I Might Be A Zombie Who's Fullitis".
That is, I think, even more disrespectful.
What are the symptoms beyond that?
Oh, what you'd expect, really.

A disconnect with life, a sense of emotional and physiological flatness which may be a symptom or a cause of the disorder. It's very rare, but one that I imagine is quite upsetting for everyone involved. Sometimes the person affected won't eat.
Creepy!

Yep! This continues a theme in my life of being terrified of all that can go wrong with my brain. Hey, you wanna invent a way to transform our minds into something non-physical so that we can live safely forever?
Sure!
RADICAL.

transcription.title: this comic goes out to my stinky sofa. oh, stinky sofa, what am i going to do with you

panel.line: Panpsychism is the belief that everything in the universe has consciousness - not just chicks and dudes, but even inorganic matter like steel! Even the stinky ol' sofa that nobody likes because it stinks when you sit on it.
DUDE THROW OUT THE SOFA
I hear you, man!

Anyway, it doesn't necessarily claim that drywall spends its time writing poems about, you know, DRYWALL STUFF - it only claims that there are some elements of sentience in everything. When you boil water it might be enjoying it, that's all. Or, it might be writhing in pain, screaming for mercy with a mouth that now speaks only with a scalding voice of steam.
Yikes!
Some panpsychists go further than that though!
Oh yeah?
Yeah: at the extreme, you have panpsychists who believe that the entire universe possesses a single mind, and that everything, including us, is a part of it.
I can see the appeal of that! Though you'd kinda have to wonder what the universe is thinking about.

transcription.title: things happen for a reason

panel.line: I don't like it when something bad happens. Well, IN PARTICULAR, I don't like it when something bad happens and people say that "there's a reason" for it happening!
It turns bad things into a value proposition!

I'm all for optimism and for comforting people, so it's not TERRIBLE, but I've always read the phrase as saying "you're sad because you got a raw deal, but ACTUALLY things will be better in the future because of this event, so you're coming out on top!" It seems very - capitalistic, I guess? Like I would want to be comforted by being told that, despite appearances, I'm actually a savvy businessman?
I think the phrase is more to try to find sense to a senseless loss, T-Rex.
I guess.
And I get that it's meant to comfort, and I respect that! I just don't like how it implies I'm sad because of a bad deal. I'm sad for the loss, you know?
What brought this on? Have you suffered any losses lately?
Just one...!
EARLIER:
God, where the heck are my socks?! I can't find any of my socks.
THINGS HAPPEN FOR A REASON T-REX
Hey, God?
SOCKS PLEASE

transcription.title: magic realism is where you tell a realistic story but then have the characters turn each other into frogs for a bit. depressive realism is different.

panel.line: Depressive realism is the theory that depressed people have a more accurate view of the world than the non depressed. It started when psychologists experimented with some regular chicks and dudes AND some depressed chicks and dudes.
That's how these things always start!!

Anyway, they put them in a room with a button and a lightbulb. The light turned on and off regardless of when the button was pressed, and the participants who were depressed were more likely to conclude that they weren't in control of the light! The non-depressed people DELUDED THEMSELVES into thinking they had more influence. The popular conclusion was that depressed people saw things more realistically!
That's a pretty strong conclusion!
Sure is!

transcription.title: sometimes newborn babies are confused and THEN cry. it can go either way, amiright?

panel.line: Okay okay - so there's been a lot of people born, right? In the history of time there are a lot of people who have been born. So the question is, are there enough people in the world that I could write out a story...
... and reasonably expect it to have already been LIVED OUT in real life?

Let's assume narratives can be reduced to yes/no decisions, and on average real people make a yes/no decision every 15 seconds. Two people are needed to cover each option for every decision! So after - um, 33 decisions, we've got more people needed than are alive now, and we're only eight minutes into our story. It is a stories-in-real-life disaster!
BUT, if I wrote a story about the first eight minutes of a baby's life, ODDS ARE someone has lived it!
Not really!
You're assuming that for each decision, every person takes a separate route, but the vast majority of babies are doing the same thing: crying and then being confused.
I guess the odds of my writing a story and having it be what ACTUALLY HAPPENED to some dude are pretty low, huh.

transcription.title: in today's comic, a dinosaur tells off shakespeare for not agreeing with him about foreshadowing! now if todd goldman puts that on a t-shirt, you'll know where he stole it from

panel.line: Foreshadowing is when you hint at what's about to happen next in a story! It happens whenever a character announces "BOY I SURE HOPE THERE ARE NO EXPLOSIONS ON THE NEXT PAGE!!" just before he gets blown up!
In an EXPLOSION!
LITERARY TECHNIQUES COMICS
today's technique: FORESHADOWING

Foreshadowing's great, because sometimes people want to know what happens in a story before it actually happens. In situations like this, an author might write "Jenn realized that she was about to blast into space. Or WAS she?? You'd better keep reading, huh?" There, foreshadowing both hinted at the future of the story, AND encouraged the reader to keep reading. This is an extremely canonical use of foreshadowing.
So doubt's important to foreshadowing?
Absolutely!
If you simply say "Jenn realized that she was about to blast into space! Seconds later, she blasted into space!" that is not foreshadowing. That is just outstanding space storytelling.
I think it's still foreshadowing.
Yeah? Well maybe we'll see what SHAKESPEARE has to say...!
MEANWHILE, IN TUDOR ENGLAND!
Shakespeare, is it still foreshadowing if it's about a woman who's DEFINITELY blasting into space?
Shakespeare: i dunno... yes?
Shakespeare! The correct answer is "no!"
Pull yourself together, Shakespeare!

transcription.title: the futurist gastronomical nightmare is a guy eating pasta with one arched eyebrow

panel.line: Futurism was an art movement where dudes were all "CARS ARE COOL AND THE PAST IS FOR CHUMPS. LET'S DRAW SOME CARS."
FUTURISM COMICS

But they also extended beyond art, to food! Futurists had a MANIFESTO for food. It banned the knife and fork and pasta, AND told people that sardines and pineapples together were tasty times! They banned pasta because it caused skepticism?
Was the food good?
Maybe? But it wasn't very popular.
People were more into the art!
Yep!

They didn't want to have to eat their food under UV lamps which "activated" it, nor did they want to give up pasta. It's crazy! The movement started in Italy, and I believe people canonically eat pasta there all the time! Like, even for breakfast?
I believe that to be Italian Canon, yes.
I got my ideas about Italy from cartoons!
Off-panel: I got mine from boxes of pasta!

I was thinking more "You know who reads comics? HORRIBLE MURDERERS." and then a picture of a horrible murderer, you know, maybe murderin' something, and THEN, in tiny letters, "and also you, hopefully!" and then maybe a line drawing of a soggy dog giving a thumbs up.

panel.line: Would I ever want to get married one day?
I don't know! Maybe!
I guess I'll burn that bridge when I come to it?

I do kinda feel like I should ALREADY know the answer to "do you want to get married someday", you know, Dromiceiomimus? Its such a big thing -- you're sharing your LIFE with someone! Until you DIE! -- that saying "if it happened it'd be nice, but no worries!" seems - disingenuous?
I guess! I know I'd like to get married someday.
I'm not ruling it out!
You're not committing to it either!

I guess love and the artifacts of affection are so played up in our society that by being noncommittal to its (arguably) greatest expression, marriage, I avoid tacitly endorsing the commercialization of an emotion and the industry surrounding it!
Perhaps!

Or perhaps I don't want to say "I WANT TO GET MARRIED SOMEDAY" because if I never meet someone then I've FAILED at a life plan. Much better to say "I WANT TO GET INTO A BOAT SOMEDAY" and then just sit in some dude's boat! IN FACT, I'm going to the docks right now!

transcription.title: guest week 2007: rebecca kraatz of house of sugar

panel.line: Beneath the Skirt of the Eastend Enchantress by Rebecca Kraatz
In 1922 in southern Saskatchewan lived a young woman, Helen, known as the Eastend Enchantress.
Helen's beauty and talent were comparable to any lass in Hollywood.
But tragedy struck when she fell off a horse and broke her leg.
Doctor: Gangrene has set in, Helen. I'm afraid... I'll... I'll have to amputate it.
Helen: Okay, doctor.
Soon after she made an announcement.
Helen: I will give my hand in marriage to the fellow who creates for me the most lovely yet comfortable fake leg.
One hundred single men went to work.
Carpenters shaped and carved wood.
A newspaper reporter made a leg of paper and wrote upon it a declaration of his devotion.
A blacksmith hammered and fused a gorgeous gam out of iron rods.
Helen carefully tried on all the legs made for her.
Helen's thoughts: Hmm?
She chose to walk down the aisle with a British Archaeologist who was passing through town.
Underneath her wedding dress was a dinosaur bone the Archaeologist had dug up in the nearby Cypress Hills.

transcription.title: guest week 2007: aaron diaz of dresdencodak.com!

panel.line: Lately I've been thinking about the role of popular culture references in popular culture!
T-REX IN: HYPERREAL COMICS

I'm getting pretty sick of nostalgic references to things like movies and video games passing for humor and creativity! People bark like trained seals any time they encounter something they're familiar with!
Heck, there are even subgenres of our culture that exist only to reference other subgenres!
Don't you think you're being kind of overzealous?
Maybe! I guess nothing's completely original, but I fear that modern media has become nothing more than a recursive loop with no discernible, objective reality!
Utrahraptor: It sounds like we're being forced to accept the classical notion that there never was any objective existence in the first place!
To be honest, all I want is a punchline that doesn't rely on reminding me of what I liked when I was 7!
LATER...
Whoops!
